Denver Nuggets s\u00fcperstar\u0131 Nikola Jokic, NBA'de 2023-24 sezonunun MVP'si se\u00e7ildi.\n\nLig tarihinde bu \u00f6d\u00fcl\u00fc en az \u00fc\u00e7 kez kazanan dokuzuncu oyuncu olmay\u0131 ba\u015faran 29 ya\u015f\u0131ndaki oyuncu, 79 birincilik oyuyla bu y\u0131l bu onuru ilk kez aday g\u00f6sterilen Oklahoma City Thunder'dan Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (15 birincilik oyu) ve Luka Doncic'e kar\u015f\u0131 (4 birincilik oyu)\n\nJokic, NBA tarihinde en az \u00fc\u00e7 kez MVP se\u00e7ilmi\u015f olan Kareem-Abdu", "deu": "Die Wahl zum wertvollsten Spieler der NBA ist eine klare Sache. Nikola Jokic bekommt die Auszeichnung verliehen. F\u00fcr ihn ist es nicht das erste Mal.\n\nNikola Jokic ist mit grossem Abstand zum wertvollsten Spieler der NBA gew\u00e4hlt worden. F\u00fcr den Serben ist es die dritte Auszeichnung in den letzten vier Jahren.\n\nDer Serbe setzt sich bei der Wahl mit 926 Punkten gegen Shai Gilgeous-Alexander von den Oklahoma City Thunder (640 Punkte) und Luka Doncic von den Dallas Mavericks (566) durch, wie die Li", "rus": "\u0421\u0435\u0440\u0431\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0439 \u0446\u0435\u043d\u0442\u0440\u043e\u0432\u043e\u0439 \"\u0414\u0435\u043d\u0432\u0435\u0440\u0430\" \u043d\u0430\u0437\u0432\u0430\u043d MVP \u041d\u0411\u0410.\n\n\u0419\u043e\u043a\u0438\u0447 \u043f\u043e\u043b\u0443\u0447\u0430\u0435\u0442 \u043d\u0430\u0433\u0440\u0430\u0434\u0443 \u0432 \u0442\u0440\u0435\u0442\u0438\u0439 \u0440\u0430\u0437, \u0440\u0430\u043d\u0435\u0435 \u043e\u043d \u0431\u0440\u0430\u043b \u044d\u0442\u043e\u0442 \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0437 \u0432 \u0441\u0435\u0437\u043e\u043d\u0430\u0445-2020/21 \u0438 2021/22. \u0412 \u043f\u0440\u043e\u0448\u043b\u043e\u043c \u0441\u0435\u0437\u043e\u043d\u0435 \u043e\u043d \u0441\u0442\u0430\u043b \u0432\u0442\u043e\u0440\u044b\u043c \u0432 \u0433\u043e\u043b\u043e\u0441\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0438 \u0436\u0443\u0440\u043d\u0430\u043b\u0438\u0441\u0442\u043e\u0432.\n\n\u0419\u043e\u043a\u0438\u0447 - 9-\u0439 \u0438\u0433\u0440\u043e\u043a \u0432 \u0438\u0441\u0442\u043e\u0440\u0438\u0438, \u043a\u043e\u0442\u043e\u0440\u044b\u0439 \u044f\u0432\u043b\u044f\u0435\u0442\u0441\u044f \u043e\u0431\u043b\u0430\u0434\u0430\u0442\u0435\u043b\u0435\u043c \u0442\u0440\u0435\u0445 \u0438\u043b\u0438 \u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0435 \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0437\u043e\u0432 MVP. \u0420\u0430\u043d\u0435\u0435 \u044d\u0442\u043e", "por": "Acabou a espera. Nikola Jokic foi eleito MVP da fase regular da NBA, conquistando a distin\u00e7\u00e3o pela terceira vez na carreira. Ali\u00e1s, o saga do s\u00e9rvio dos Denver Nuggets foi interrompida por Joel Embiid (Philadelphia 76ers) na temporada passada, mas tinha vencido as duas edi\u00e7\u00f5es anteriores de forma consecutiva.\n\nAssim, o basquetebolista, de 29 anos, bateu a forte concorr\u00eancia de Lukas Doncic (Dallas Mavericks) e Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Oklahoma Thunder), igualando o registo de pr\u00e9mios MVP "}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Oklahoma City"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Professional", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Professional", "wgt": 95}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Fan_Pages", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Fan Pages", "wgt": 77}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/History", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/History", "wgt": 57}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 93}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 200, "spa": 67, "fra": 29, "srp": 27, "tur": 10, "deu": 11, "rus": 13, "por": 11}, "sentiment": 0.3254901960784313}
{"uri": "2024-05-349603269", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:03:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:03:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:55:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.cbs17.com/sports/ap-jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-his-3rd-in-4-seasons-gilgeous-alexander-and-doncic-round-out-top-3/", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons. Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic round out top 3", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nNew York's Jalen Brunson was fifth.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "cbs17.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS17.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@cbs17.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TNT_(American_TV_network)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "TNT (American TV network)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Russell", "type": "https://www.cbs17.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/29/2024/05/663c116a5bb6d1.35109682.jpeg?strip=1&w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": null, {"uri": "2024-05-349609667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:15:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:15:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.wlwt.com/article/jokic-wins-nba-mvp-award-2024/60737707", "title": "Denver Nuggets' Nikola Jokic wins third NBA MVP award in four seasons", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.Jokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.Related video above: Denver Nuggets defeated Miami Heat in 2023 to clinch first championship in franchise historyHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.Jokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"It likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.Oklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.This time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth.\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"Jokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners. Jokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.The other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.Gilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month. Doncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.And this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.But in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"___AP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report.\n\nNikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nRelated video above: Denver Nuggets defeated Miami Heat in 2023 to clinch first championship in franchise history\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nNew York's Jalen Brunson was fifth.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "wlwt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "https://kubrick.htvapps.com/htv-prod-media.s3.amazonaws.com/images/ap2663c131aa05ef.jpg?crop=1.00xw:0.847xh;0,0.0144xh&resize=640:*", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-02", "dateEnd": "-03-04", "textStart": 1948, "textEnd": 1955, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": 0.3803921568627451, "wgt": 230, {"uri": "2024-05-349625265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:50:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:50:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:09:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.sudbury.com/national-sports/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-finishing-ahead-of-canadas-gilgeous-alexander-in-voting-8718906", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, finishing ahead of Canada's Gilgeous-Alexander in voting", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player, topping Canada's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder in the voting.\n\nIt was the third time Jokic has won the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander, from Hamilton, Ont., was ahead of Dallas' Luka Doncic as both got into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nNew York's Jalen Brunson was fifth.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA\n\nTim Reynolds, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "sudbury.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sudbury.com"}, "https://www.vmcdn.ca/f/files/shared/feeds/cp/2024/05/20240508190536-663c0ca26013bbf0db3337aajpeg.jpg;w=1200;h=800;mode=crop", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-02", "dateEnd": "-03-04", "textStart": 1246, "textEnd": 1253}], "sentiment": 0.3176470588235294, "wgt": 230, {"uri": "2024-05-349687401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:57:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:57:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:35:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/08/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-his-3rd-in-4-seasons-gilgeous-alexander-and-doncic-round-out-top-3/", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons. Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic round out top 3", "body": "FILE - Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic (15) shoots against Memphis Grizzlies guard Jordan Goodwin (4) in the second half of an NBA basketball game, Sunday, April 14, 2024, in Memphis, Tenn. Jokic, Luka Doncic and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander are the three finalists for the NBA MVP Award that will be announced Wednesday, May 8, 2024. [...]\n\nNikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\n\"To be honest, I'm wearing this shirt pretty much every day, especially when I'm in the training facility,\" Jokic said. \"Deki was the guy who gave me the freedom. He showed me the way how you're supposed to do things -- act, train, workout. ... He trusted me and I can just say, 'thank you.'\"\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver {"uri": "8118234199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:16:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:16:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:16:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/sports/national-sports/2024/05/08/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-finishing-ahead-of-canadas-gilgeousalexander-in-voting/", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, finishing ahead of Canada's Gilgeous-Alexander in voting - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again. Jokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player, topping Canada's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder in the voting. It was the third time Jokic has won the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished. He averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category - and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories - but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season. Gilgeous-Alexander, from Hamilton, Ont., was ahead of Dallas' Luka Doncic as both got into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting. This time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth - so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth. \"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\"\u009d Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\u009d Jokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended. \"It's got to start with your teammates,\"\u009d Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\u009d It likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u00c4\u2021, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip. Jokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners. Jokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29. The other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years - joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan. Gilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players. \"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. \"| There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\"\u009d Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month. Doncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season - of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds. And this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season. But in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others - and the vote wasn't close. \"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\u009d ___ AP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report. ___ AP NBA:", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "canadian_press@medicinehatnews.com", "name": {"uri": "8119683179", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:22:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:22:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:21:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/denver-nuggets-center-nikola-jokic-makes-history-with-third-nba-mvp-award-5646776", "title": "Denver Nuggets Center Nikola Jokic Makes History With Third NBA MVP Award", "body": "Nikola Jokic becomes the ninth player in NBA history, and first foreign player, to win at least three MVP awards.\n\nNikola Jokic becomes the ninth player in NBA history, and first foreign player, to win at least three MVP awards. He defeated finalists Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Luka Doncic in runaway fashion.\n\nEver since the NBA announced its three finalists for the Most Valuable Player award for the 2023-24 season, many have assumed it was just a matter of time until Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic collected his third trophy.\n\nTheir assumptions were right as Jokic was named the league's MVP on Wednesday night, joining the two awards he won in the 2020-21 and 2021-22 seasons. Jokic, Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder, and Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks were the three finalists, but Jokic easily outpaced his two contemporaries in voting. Jokic finished with 79 of the 99 first-place votes, followed by Gilgeous-Alexander (15), Doncic (four), with Giannis Antetokounmpo of Milwaukee received the one other first-place vote.\n\nThe overall voting had Jokic with 926 points, with Gilgeous-Alexander runner-up (640 points) and Doncic third (566). A total of eight players received votes with Antetokounmpo fourth, Jalen Brunson of the Knicks fifth, Jayson Tatum of the Celtics sixth, Anthony Edwards of the Timberwolves seventh, Domantas Sabonis of the Kings eighth, and Kevin Durant of the Suns ninth.\n\nWith the finalists being Jokic from Serbia, Doncic from Slovenia, and Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada, it was guaranteed that a foreign-born player would win the award for the sixth straight season. There were just four winners born outside of the United States during the first 72 seasons of the NBA.\n\nIn his eighth NBA season, Jokic averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds, and 9.0 assists per game, ranking in the top 10 in all three stats. It was just the second season in NBA history in which a player averaged at least 25 points, 12 rebounds, and eight assists, joining Oscar Robertson in 1961-62. Jokic also shot 58.3 percent from the field and posted 25 triple-doubles as he led the Nuggets to the second seed in the Western Conference and a 57-25 overall record, which ties for the third-best mark in franchise history.\n\nWith the win, Jokic becomes the ninth player in NBA history with at least three MVP awards, but he also became the first to accomplish another feat. By winning the NBA Finals MVP award last season as the Nuggets won their first championship in franchise history, Jokic becomes the first player to win either an NBA MVP or Finals MVP in four straight seasons.\n\nThe only players with more regular season MVP awards than Jokic are LeBron James and Wilt Chamberlain (four each), Michael Jordan and Bill Russell (five each), and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (six).\n\nThis season is the first in which the NBA established a minimum games played criteria in order to be eligible for end-of-season awards such as MVP. Players must have played in at least 65 of the 82 games, and they must have been on the court for at least 20 minutes during those 65 games. With that threshold in place, last year's MVP winner, Joel Embiid, was ineligible for the award after playing in 39 games even though he ended up leading the NBA with 34.7 points per game.\n\nConsidered one of the most selfless athletes in all of sports, Jokic was deferential when asked by Ernie Johnson of TNT where he would begin with recognition for the award.\n\n\"It's got to start with my teammates,\" Jokic replied. \"Without them, I'm nothing, and without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, strength coaches, development coaches. It's all one big circle that, I cannot be where I am without them.\"\n\nHe then credited a handful of individuals within the Nuggets when asked who most helped him get to this point as a three-time NBA MVP winner.\n\n\"Since I've came here to Denver and the Nuggets organization, individually I'm working with three people,\" Jokic said. \"It's [athletic trainer] Jason Miller, it's [strength and conditioning coach] Felipe [Eichenberger] and it's [assistant coach] Ogi [Stojakovic]. It's those guys who've worked with me closely, and of course coach [Michael Malone], who I've been with eight years. And Jamal [Murray] is the guy I played with the most in this organization. And my family -- they're always with me, always around me.\"\n\nWhile winning the MVP award is certainly a great honor, it hasn't been a predictor of postseason success for recent winners, including the last two times Jokic won. Prior to this season, the last eight MVP winners failed to win an NBA championship in the season they won the award. Steph Curry in 2014-15 was the last MVP winner to then go on to win the championship that season.\n\nJokic and the Nuggets lost in the second round of the playoffs when he won in 2020-21 and then lost in the first round when he repeated a season later. On the night he won his third MVP award, Jokic and the Nuggets find themselves in an 0-2 hole in the second round of the playoffs to the Minnesota Timberwolves.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8118345780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:36:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:36:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:36:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/5/9/jokic-wins-nba-s-mvp-award-his-3rd-in-4-seasons", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons", "body": "Jokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night, May 8, as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nNikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night, May 8, as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\n\"To be honest, I'm wearing this shirt pretty much every day, especially when I'm in the training facility,\" Jokic said. \"Deki was the guy who gave me the freedom. He showed me the way how you're supposed to do things -- act, train, workout. ... He trusted me and I can just say, 'thank you.'\"\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"", "source": {"uri": "mb.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila {"uri": "2024-05-349763566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:00:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:00:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:59:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/565296/nikola-jokic-wins-nba-mvp-award-his-third-in-four-seasons", "title": "Nikola Jokic wins NBA MVP award, his third in four seasons", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\nREAD: NBA: Jokic shows up to Game 1 dressed like 'Gru' from 'Despicable Me'\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nREAD: NBA: Jokic trying to stay on top, Embiid trying to stay on court\n\n\"To be honest, I'm wearing this shirt pretty much every day, especially when I'm in the training facility,\" Jokic said. \"Deki was the guy who gave me the freedom. He showed me the way how you're supposed to do things -- act, train, workout. ... He trusted me and I can just say, 'thank you.'\"\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic round out top 3", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic round out top 3", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that an player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. {"uri": "8118210823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:09:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:09:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:48:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13398043/Jokic-wins-NBAs-MVP-award-3rd-4-seasons-Gilgeous-Alexander-Doncic-round-3.html", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons....", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player - his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category - and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories - but he was the only player to rank in the NBA\u00b4s top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It\u00b4s got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I\u00b4m nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u00b4c, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nFILE - Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic (15) shoots against Memphis Grizzlies guard Jordan Goodwin (4) in the second half of an NBA basketball game, Sunday, April 14, 2024, in Memphis, Tenn. Jokic, Luka Doncic and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander are the three finalists for the NBA MVP Award that will be announced Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Brandon Dill, File)\n\nOklahoma City\u00b4s Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas\u00b4 Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee\u00b4s Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth - so this became the first time in the award\u00b4s 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nNew York's Jalen Brunson was fifth.\n\n\"Some people say it\u00b4s the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it\u00b4s the guy who\u00b4s the most valuable, the team couldn\u00b4t play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic\u00b4s surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn\u00b4t even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years - joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander\u00b4s emergence as one of the game\u00b4s elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don\u00b4t feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There\u00b4s no one I\u00b4d rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league\u00b4s coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season - of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia\u00b4s Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City\u00b4s Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season\u00b4s MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others - and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he\u00b4s stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It\u00b4s hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he\u00b4s a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he\u00b4s delivered.\"\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report.\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA\n\nFILE - Oklahoma City Thunder guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, left, scores against Golden State Warriors guard Brandin Podziemski, middle, and forward Dario Saric during the second half of an NBA basketball game in San Francisco, Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Gilgeous-Alexander, Nikola Jokic and Luka Doncic are the three finalists for the NBA MVP Award that will be announced Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, File)\n\nFILE - Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic, center, shoots as Los Angeles Clippers guard Norman Powell, right, defends during the second half in Game 5 of an NBA basketball first-round playoff series Wednesday, May 1, 2024, in Los Angeles. Doncic, Nikola Jokic and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander are the three finalists for the NBA MVP Award that will be announced Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Mark J. Terrill, File)\n\nFILE - From left are Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic, Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic and Oklahoma City Thunder guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander in 2023. Jokic, Doncic and Gilgeous-Alexander are the three finalists for the NBA MVP Award that will be announced Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/File)\n\nDenver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic, left, looks to pass the ball as Minnesota Timberwolves center Naz Reid defends during the second half of Game 2 of an NBA basketball second-round playoff series, Monday, May 6, 2024, in Denver. (AP Photo/David Zalubowski)\n\nDenver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic drops back to defend during the second half of Game 2 of an NBA basketball second-round playoff series against the Minnesota Timberwolves, Monday, May 6, 2024, in Denver. {"uri": "8118361067", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:54:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:54:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:54:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/may/08/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-his-3rd-in-4-seasons/", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\n\"To be honest, I'm wearing this shirt pretty much every day, especially when I'm in the training facility,\" Jokic said. \"Deki was the guy who gave me the freedom. He showed me the way how you're supposed to do things -- act, train, workout. ... He trusted me and I can just say, 'thank you.'\"\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"", "source": {"uri": "newstribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
