"wgt": 100}], "image": "https://wehco.media.clients.ellingtoncms.com/img/photos/2024/05/08/nhl_t600.jpg?4326734cdb8e39baa3579048ef63ad7b451e7676", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-02", "dateEnd": "-03-04", "textStart": 1580, "textEnd": 1587}], "sentiment": 0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 224, {"uri": "8118311712", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:53:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:53:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:52:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/denvers-jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-for-third-time-in-four-seasons-5646630", "title": "Denver's Jokic Wins NBA's MVP Award for Third Time in Four Seasons", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the NBA's most valuable player trophy is his again, as well.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the league's MVP for the third time in the past four seasons -- a feat that just six other players in NBA history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds, and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds, and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic received 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State Warriors assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Luka Doncic of Dallas was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada, and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the United States finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced. Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place, and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird, and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning, and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain, and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell, and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds, and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder Coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds, and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court, and he's delivered.\"", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8118682114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:36:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:36:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:36:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/may/09/serbian-superstar-a-three-time-mvp/", "title": "Serbian superstar a three-time MVP", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said in an interview with TNT. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevic, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder Coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, 9 rebounds and 9 assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\nFILE - Oklahoma City Thunder guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, left, scores against Golden State Warriors guard Brandin Podziemski, middle, and forward Dario Saric during the second half of an NBA basketball game in San Francisco, Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Gilgeous-Alexander, Nikola Jokic and Luka Doncic are the three finalists for the NBA MVP Award that will be announced Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, File)\n\nFILE - Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic, center, shoots as Los Angeles Clippers guard Norman Powell, right, defends during the second half in Game 5 of an NBA basketball first-round playoff series Wednesday, May 1, 2024, in Los Angeles. Doncic, Nikola Jokic and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander are the three finalists for the NBA MVP Award that will be announced Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Mark J. Terrill, File)\n\nFILE - From left are Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic, Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic and Oklahoma City Thunder guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander in 2023. Jokic, Doncic and Gilgeous-Alexander are the three finalists for the NBA MVP Award that will be announced Wednesday, May 8, 2024. "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-02", "dateEnd": "-03-04", "textStart": 1835, "textEnd": 1842}, {"amb": false, "date": "2018-11-", "textStart": 5542, "textEnd": 5549}], "sentiment": 0.1843137254901961, "wgt": 224, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8118242464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:28:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:28:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:27:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/sports/basketball/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-finishing-ahead-of-canadas-gilgeous-alexander-in-voting/article_4ac1f731-d227-5c36-ad68-4c9631e150a6.html", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, finishing ahead of Canada's Gilgeous-Alexander in voting", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player, topping Canada's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder in the voting.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nIt was the third time Jokic has won the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander, from Hamilton, Ont., was ahead of Dallas' Luka Doncic as both got into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nNew York's Jalen Brunson was fifth.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\n___\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": It also became the sixth consecutive year that an player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. {"eng": "Joel Embiid"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Conference_(NBA)", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Western Conference (NBA)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Associated Press"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Philadelphia"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Philadelphia"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Fan_Pages", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Fan Pages", "wgt": 19}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Coaching", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Coaching", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Lacrosse/Drills_and_Coaching", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Lacrosse/Drills and Coaching", "wgt": 17}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/History", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/History", "wgt": "https://www.usnews.com/dims4/USNEWS/ce2031b/2147483647/thumbnail/970x647/quality/85/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.usnews.com%2Fcmsmedia%2F01%2F4b895589b2e961d1b0f68a09ce4558%2Fe42934e1271a457ba2fd28ca2af0bb83NBA_MVP_Basketball_75449.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-02", "dateEnd": "-03-04", "textStart": 1314, "textEnd": 1321}], "sentiment": 0.3098039215686275, "wgt": 220, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8119286838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:12:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:12:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:11:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "http://sentinelcolorado.com/sports/pro/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-his-3rd-in-4-seasons-gilgeous-alexander-and-doncic-round-out-top-3/", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons. Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic round out top 3 - Sentinel Colorado", "body": "Jokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots\n\nNikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 33 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\nThis story has been corrected to Doncic averaging 33 points, not 34.\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "sentinelcolorado.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sentinel Colorado"}, "authors": "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-02", "dateEnd": "-03-04", "textStart": 908, "textEnd": 915}], "sentiment": 0.3725490196078431, "wgt": 219, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8119771965", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:46:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:46:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:46:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.newson6.com/story/663d31af136c2e064936ef30/sga-finishes-2nd-in-nba-mvp-voting-as-jokic-wins-award-for-3rd-time-in-4-seasons", "title": "SGA Finishes 2nd In NBA MVP Voting As Jokic Wins Award For 3rd Time In 4 Seasons", "body": "Oklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time\n\nNikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 33 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\nThis story has been corrected to Doncic averaging 33 points, not 34.\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "newson6.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News On 6"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-349796563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:43:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:43:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:17:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-his-3rd-in-4-seasons-gilgeous-alexander-and-doncic-round/article_c6e3d8fb-4610-593c-9234-1f1559819911.html", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons. Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic round out top 3", "body": "Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\n\"To be honest, I'm wearing this shirt pretty much every day, especially when I'm in the training facility,\" Jokic said. \"Deki was the guy who gave me the freedom. He showed me the way how you're supposed to do things -- act, train, workout. ... He trusted me and I can just say, 'thank you.'\"\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\nAP Sports Writers Arnie Stapleton and Pat Graham in Denver contributed to this report.\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA\n\nMore from this section\n\nHuman Rights Group Demands the American Psychiatric Association Ban ECT and End All Harmful and Coercive {"uri": "8118946160", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:29:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:29:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:27:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1320610", "title": "Nuggets' Nikola Jokic wins NBA MVP for 3rd time in 4 seasons", "body": "Denver Nuggets superstar Nikola Jokic continued to add to his legacy as one of the best NBA players ever by winning his third Most Valuable Player trophy on Wednesday.\n\nJokic earned the award for the third time in four seasons, succeeding last season's MVP, Philadelphia 76ers center Joel Embiid. Jokic topped Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder and Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks, who finished second and third, respectively, in the voting.\n\n\"It's got to start with the teammates; without them, I cannot do nothing,\" Jokic said Wednesday on TNT after being named MVP. \"Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, strength coaches, development coaches. It is all one big circle. But I cannot be whatever I am without them.\"\n\nJokic's third MVP victory wasn't close. He garnered 79 first-place votes and a total of 926 points. Gilgeous-Alexander received 15 first-place votes and 640 points. Doncic claimed four first-place votes and 566 points. The Milwaukee Bucks' Giannis Antetokounmpo finished fourth, and New York Knicks guard Jalen Brunson was fifth in voting.\n\n\"There's a lot of players that deserve it,\" Jokic said of the MVP race. \"It's probably details and the small things [that determine it].\"\n\nJokic is the first center in six decades to win MVP three times in four seasons; Kareem Abdul-Jabbar did so from 1973-74 to 1976-77. Jokic also is the ninth player in the NBA history to win at least three MVPs, joining Abdul-Jabbar (6 total), Michael Jordan (5), Bill Russell (4), LeBron James (4), Wilt Chamberlain, Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson.\n\n\"It's hard to differentiate greatness from greatness from greatness,\" Denver coach Michael Malone said in early April of how Jokic has gotten better from previous MVP seasons. \"And then that's what he's been over multiple years now. I know the last six years now, we've had by far the best record in the Western Conference and only second of the NBA behind, I think, Milwaukee in that time.\"\n\nIn his ninth season, Jokic played 79 games, his most since logging 80 games during the 2018-19 season. He joined Chamberlain as the only players in NBA history to finish in the top five in total points (fifth), rebounds (third) and assists (second) in multiple seasons, according to research by ESPN Stats & Information. Elgin Baylor is the only other player to do so once.\n\nJokic is also the second player to record 2,000 points, 900 rebounds and 600 assists in a season, joining Oscar Robertson.\n\nJokic averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists -- all in the top 10 in each statistical category. He had 25 triple-doubles, second only to the Sacramento Kings' Domantas Sabonis (26), while averaging 58.3% shooting from the field and 35.9% from behind the arc.\n\nPowered by Jokic, Denver finished the season fifth in offensive efficiency, eighth in defensive efficiency and fourth in net rating. The Nuggets were one of four teams to rank in the top 10 in all three, along with the Boston Celtics, New York Knicks and Oklahoma City Thunder.\n\nWhile Denver boasted the best starting five in the league, Jokic's value was undeniable to Denver. The Nuggets posted a plus-11.8 net efficiency when Jokic was on the court but a minus-8.6 when he was off the court. Jokic led the NBA with a plus-682 plus-minus. The Nuggets were minus-251 with their franchise player off the court.\n\nOf course, the humble Jokic often says he doesn't care about individual honors as much as he covets the championship. Jokic is trying to lead the Nuggets to a repeat as world champs.\n\nShould he do so, the Nuggets big man will have put together a four-year run that only four other all-time greats have done. Russell, Bird, Johnson and James are the only players to win three regular-season MVPs and two NBA titles in a four-year span.\n\n\"Nikola has matured, his ability to continue to make everyone around him better,\" Malone said. \"And when you win a championship, and we're going to run it back, but in place of Bruce [Brown] and Jeff [Green], we're going to try to put young players in and the fact that we have a better record than we did last year.\n\n\"And we've had Jamal Murray miss [23] games. It speaks to Nikola understanding it's still my responsibility as a great player to help [the younger role players] as well as all the other guys to understand what their roles are, how to play on both ends of the floor and, most importantly, make those guys better.\"\n\nESPN's Stats & Information contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBB"}, {"uri": "8118220639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:01:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:01:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:00:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/sports/national-sports/2024/05/08/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-his-3rd-in-4-seasons-gilgeousalexander-and-doncic-round-out-top-3/", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons. Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic round out top 3 - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW Nikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again. Jokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player - his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished. He averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category - and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories - but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season. Jokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended. Oklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting. This time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth - so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that an player born outside the U.S. won the award. Jokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners. Jokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29. The other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years - joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan. Gilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players. \"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. \"| There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\"\u009d Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month. Doncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season - of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds. And this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season. ___ AP NBA:", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": Without them, I cannot do nothing.\n\n\"Coaches, players, organisation, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time.\n\nWith Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it was the third consecutive season that three players born outside the US finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance was even more pronounced.\n\nMilwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, from Greece, was fourth, marking the first time in the award's 69-year history international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting.\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, while Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five.\n\nWilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, with Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell.\n\n\"He's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said of his teammate.\n\n\"It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game.\n\n\"He does it with a smile on his face and he makes everybody around us better.\n\n\"And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No.1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists.\n\nThe Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding {"uri": "2024-05-349694568", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "03:07:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T03:07:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:07:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://cebudailynews.inquirer.net/572461/nuggetsjokic-is-nba-mvp-again", "title": "Nuggets'Jokic is NBA MVP again", "body": "Los Angeles, United States-Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic was named NBA Most valuable Player (MVP) for the third time in four seasons on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nThe 29-year-old Serbian star, who won the award in 2021 and 2022, finished runner-up in the voting in 2023 but had the satisfaction of leading the Nuggets to a first NBA title.\n\nThis season he averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists in the regular season and beat out Oklahoma City Thunder star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks in final voting for the award.\n\nIn another season in which Jokic managed to make brilliance almost look routine, he became the second player, after Oscar Robertson, to record 2,000 points, 900 rebounds and 600 assists in a season.\n\nHis 25 triple-doubles and 68 double-doubles were both second in the league.\n\nElite company\n\nJokic enters elite territory with a third MVP crown. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's six MVPs are the most ever. Bill Russell and Michael Jordan won five apiece and Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James four.\n\nJokic joins Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson as three-time winners after earning 79 first-placed votes compared to 15 for Gilgeous-Alexander and four for Doncic.\n\n\"We've got to start with the teammates. Without them I cannot do anything,\" Jokic said in the MVP announcement broadcast on TNT when asked to reflect on yet another MVP.\n\nREAD MORE:\n\nNBA: Jokic, Doncic and Gilgeous-Alexander finalists for MVP award\n\n\"Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, across time coaches, development coaches -- it's all one big circle that I cannot be wherever I am without them.\"\n\nBehind Jokic, the 57-25 Nuggets matched the franchise high for victories in a season -- although they were tied for best record in the West with Oklahoma City and ended up with the second seed behind the young Thunder team.\n\nDeserving MVP\n\nAs always, the MVP award offered plenty of scope for argument.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander, a 25-year-old Canadian, averaged 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds, 6.2 assists and 2.0 steals per game for upstarts Oklahoma City and had a league-high 51 30-point games.\n\nSlovenia's Doncic led the league in scoring with 33.9 points per game and ranked second in assists with 9.8 per game. He averaged 9.2 rebounds per game and became the third player to average a 30-point triple-double after the All-Star break after Oscar Robertson (1961-62) and Russell Westbrook (2016-17).\n\nBut Nuggets coach Mike Malone was in no doubt that Jokic's third MVP was richly deserved.\n\n\"I don't know if I can put that into words what his greatness means to every team,\" Malone said last month, adding that he particularly admired the fact that winning the award was \"not his motivation.\"\n\n\"When he gets up in the morning ... he's not doing it for the individual accolades and recognition,\" Malone said. \"He's doing it for the collective to win and hopefully win another championship. That's what he's all about.\"\n\nMalone on Jokic: Excellence every night\n\nMalone said Jokic was a classic example of a player who makes the rest of his team better.\n\n\"That is what I marvel at, most importantly with Nikola as a player. Just the consistent greatness and how he finds ways to every single night, no matter who is available around him, to bring that level of excellence every night,\" Malone said.\n\n\"Basically, put that team on his back and make each and every one of his teammates that much better.\"\n\nWhen Jokic won the 2022 MVP he was already back home in Sombor, Serbia, in the wake of the Nuggets' playoff exit.\n\nWhether Jokic will be able to combine an MVP award and the title this season remains to be seen.\n\nThe Nuggets dropped the first two games of their Western Conference semi-final series to the Minnesota Timberwolves and face the tough task of trying to claw back on the Timberwolves' home court starting on Friday.\n\nJokic's victory marks the sixth straight season that the MVP award has gone to a player born outside the United States. The last US-born player to win was James Harden in 2018.", "source": {"uri": "cebudailynews.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "CDN Digital"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118240666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:25:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:25:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:24:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://ksltv.com/642652/nikola-jokic-wins-third-career-nba-mvp-award/", "title": "Nikola Joki\u0107 Wins Third Career NBA MVP Award", "body": "DENVER, Colorado - Nikola Joki\u0107 did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJoki\u0107, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJoki\u0107 got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Joki\u0107 said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Joki\u0107 appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevi\u0107, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nNew York's Jalen Brunson was fifth.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.\n\nBut in the end, it was Jokic who stood above all others -- and the vote wasn't close.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" Nuggets guard Jamal Murray said. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every game. He does it with a smile on his face. He makes everybody around us better. And he's a leader on the court and somebody that we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court and he's delivered.\"", "source": {"uri": "ksltv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8118220596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:02:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:02:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:00:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://africa.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/40109006/nuggets-nikola-jokic-wins-nba-mvp-3rd-4-seasons", "title": "Jokic wins 3rd NBA MVP; SGA, Doncic finish 2-3", "body": "Ohm Youngmisuk has covered the Giants, Jets and the NFL since 2006. Prior to that, he covered the Nets, Knicks and the NBA for nearly a decade. He joined ESPNNewYork.com after working at the New York Daily News for almost 12 years and is a graduate of Michigan State University.\n\nFollow him on Twitter \" Ohm's chat archive \"\n\nDenver Nuggets superstar Nikola Jokic continued to add to his legacy as one of the best NBA players ever Wednesday by winning his third Most Valuable Player trophy.\n\nJokic won the award for the third time in four seasons, succeeding last season's MVP, Philadelphia 76ers center Joel Embiid. He topped Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder and Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks, who finished second and third, respectively, in the voting.\n\n\"It's got to start with the teammates, without them, I cannot do nothing,\" Jokic said on TNT after earning the award on Wednesday. \"Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, strength coaches, development coaches. It is all one big circle. But I cannot be whatever I am without them.\"\n\nJokic's third MVP victory wasn't close. He garnered 79 first-place votes and a total of 926 points. Gilgeous-Alexander received 15 first-place votes and 640 points. Doncic got four first-place votes and 566 points. The Milwaukee Bucks' Giannis Antetokounmpo finished fourth and New York Knicks guard Jalen Brunson was fifth in voting.\n\n\"There's a lot of players that deserve it,\" Jokic said of the MVP race. \"It's probably details and the small things [that determine it].\"\n\nJokic is the first center in six decades to win MVP three times in four seasons; Kareem Abdul-Jabbar did it from 1973-74 to 1976-77.\n\n\"It's hard to differentiate greatness from greatness from greatness,\" Denver head coach Michael Malone said in early April of how Jokic has gotten better from previous MVP seasons. \"And then that's what he's been over multiple years now. I know the last six years now, we've had by far the best record in the Western Conference and only second of the NBA behind, I think Milwaukee in that time.\"\n\nIn his ninth season, Jokic played 79 games, his most since playing 80 games during the 2018-19 season. He joined Wilt Chamberlain as the only players in NBA history to finish top-five in total points (fifth), rebounds (third) and assists (second) in multiple seasons, according to research by ESPN Stats & Information. Elgin Baylor is the only other player to do so once.\n\nJokic is also the second player to record 2,000 points, 900 rebounds and 600 assists in a season, joining Oscar Robertson.\n\nJokic averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists -- all top 10 in each statistical category. He had 25 triple-doubles, second only to Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis (26), while averaging 58.3% shooting from the field and 35.9% from behind the arc.\n\nPowered by Jokic, Denver finished the season fifth in offensive efficiency, eighth in defensive efficiency, and fourth in net rating. The Nuggets were one of four teams to rank top-10 in all three, along with the Celtics, Knicks and Thunder.\n\nWhile Denver boasted the best starting five in the league, Jokic's value was undeniable to Denver. The Nuggets posted a plus-11.8 net efficiency when Jokic was on the court but a minus-8.6 when he was off. Jokic led the NBA with a plus-682 plus-minus. The Nuggets were minus-251 with their franchise player off the court.\n\nOf course, the humble Jokic often says he doesn't care about individual honors as much as he covets the championship. Jokic is trying to lead the Nuggets to a repeat as world champs.\n\nShould he do so, the Nuggets big man will have put together a four-year run that only four other all-time greats have ever done. LeBron James, Magic Johnson, Larry Bird and Bill Russell are the only players to win three regular-season MVPs and two titles in a four-year span.\n\n\"Nikola has matured, his ability to continue to make everyone around him better,\" Malone said. \"And when you win a championship, and we're going to run it back, but in place of Bruce [Brown] and Jeff [Green], we're going to try to put young players in and the fact that we have a better record than we did last year.\n\n\"And we've had Jamal Murray miss [23] games. It speaks to Nikola understanding it's still my responsibility as a great player to help [the younger role players] as well as all the other guys to understand what their roles are, how to play on both ends of the floor, and most importantly, make those guys better.\"", "source": {"uri": "africa.espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118306661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:47:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:47:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:46:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/sports/sports-headlines/basketball/314444972/nuggets-jokic-scoops-third-nba-most-valuable-player-award.html", "title": "Nuggets' Jokic scoops third NBA Most Valuable Player award - Manila Standard", "body": "Los Angeles, United States -- Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic was named NBA Most valuable Player for the third time in four seasons on Wednesday.\n\nThe 29-year-old Serbian star, who won the award in 2021 and 2022, finished runner-up in the voting in 2023 but had the satisfaction of leading the Nuggets to a first NBA title.\n\nThis season he averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists in the regular season. Jokic beat out Oklahoma City Thunder star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks in final voting for the award.\n\nIn another season in which Jokic managed to make brilliance almost look routine, he became the second player, after Oscar Robertson, to record 2,000 points, 900 rebounds and 600 assists in a season.\n\nHis 25 triple-doubles and 68 double-doubles were both second in the league.\n\nJokic enters elite territory with a third MVP crown. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's six MVPs are the most ever. Bill Russell and Michael Jordan won five apiece and Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James four.\n\nJokic joins Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson as three-time winners after earning 79 first place votes compared to 15 for Gilgeous-Alexander and four for Doncic.\n\n\"We've got to start with the teammates. Without them I cannot do anything,\" Jokic said in the MVP announcement broadcast on TNT when asked to reflect on yet another plum.\n\n\"Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, across time coaches, development coaches -- it's all one big circle that I cannot be wherever I am without them.\"\n\nBehind Jokic, the 57-25 Nuggets matched the franchise high for victories in a season -- although they were tied for best record in the West with Oklahoma City and ended up with the second seed behind the young Thunder team.\n\nAs always, the MVP award offered plenty of scope for argument.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander, a 25-year-old Canadian, averaged 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds, 6.2 assists and 2.0 steals per game for upstarts Oklahoma City and had a league-high 51 30-point games.\n\nSlovenia's Doncic led the league in scoring with 33.9 points per game and ranked second in assists with 9.8 per game. He averaged 9.2 rebounds per game and became the third player to average a 30-point triple-double after the All-Star break after Oscar Robertson (1961-62) and Russell Westbrook (2016-17).\n\nBut Nuggets coach Mike Malone was in no doubt that Jokic's third MVP was richly deserved.\n\n\"I don't know if I can put that into words what his greatness means to every team,\" Malone said last month, adding that he particularly admired the fact that winning the award was \"not his motivation.\"\n\n\"When he gets up in the morning ... he's not doing it for the individual accolades and recognition,\" Malone said. \"He's doing it for the collective to win and hopefully win another championship. That's what he's all about.\"\n\nMalone said Jokic was a classic example of a player who makes the rest of his team better.\n\nWhen Jokic won the 2022 MVP he was already back home in Sombor, Serbia, in the wake of the Nuggets' playoff exit.\n\nWhether Jokic will be able to combine an MVP award and the title this season remains to be seen.\n\nThe Nuggets dropped the first two games of their Western Conference semi-final series to the Minnesota Timberwolves and face the tough task of trying to claw back on the Timberwolves' home court starting on Friday.\n\nJokic's victory marks the sixth straight season that the MVP award has gone to a player born outside the United States. The last US-born player to win was James Harden in 2018.", "source": {"uri": "manilastandard.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Standard"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8119221051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:29:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:29:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:28:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.myjoyonline.com/nba-denver-nuggets-nikola-jokic-clinches-third-mvp-award-in-4-seasons/", "title": "NBA: Denver Nuggets' Nikola Jokic clinches third MVP Award in 4 seasons - MyJoyOnline", "body": "Denver Nuggets superstar Nikola Jokic continued to add to his legacy as one of the best NBA players ever by winning his third Most Valuable Player trophy on Wednesday.\n\nJokic earned the award for the third time in four seasons, succeeding last season's MVP, Philadelphia 76ers center Joel Embiid. Jokic topped Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder and Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks, who finished second and third, respectively, in the voting.\n\n\"It's got to start with the teammates; without them, I cannot do nothing,\" Jokic said Wednesday on TNT after being named MVP. \"Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, strength coaches, development coaches. It is all one big circle. But I cannot be whatever I am without them.\"\n\nJokic's third MVP victory wasn't close. He garnered 79 first-place votes and a total of 926 points. Gilgeous-Alexander received 15 first-place votes and 640 points. Doncic claimed four first-place votes and 566 points. The Milwaukee Bucks' Giannis Antetokounmpo finished fourth, and New York Knicks guard Jalen Brunson was fifth in voting.\n\n\"There's a lot of players that deserve it,\" Jokic said of the MVP race. \"It's probably details and the small things [that determine it].\"\n\nJokic is the first center in six decades to win MVP three times in four seasons; Kareem Abdul-Jabbar did so from 1973-74 to 1976-77. Jokic also is the ninth player in the NBA history to win at least three MVPs, joining Abdul-Jabbar (6 total), Michael Jordan (5), Bill Russell (4), LeBron James (4), Wilt Chamberlain, Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson.\n\n\"It's hard to differentiate greatness from greatness from greatness,\" Denver coach Michael Malone said in early April of how Jokic has gotten better from previous MVP seasons. \"And then that's what he's been over multiple years now. I know the last six years now, we've had by far the best record in the Western Conference and only second of the NBA behind, I think, Milwaukee in that time.\"\n\nThe humble Jokic often says he doesn't care about individual honors as much as he covets the championship. Jokic is trying to lead the Nuggets to a repeat as world champs.\n\nShould he do so, the Nuggets big man will have put together a four-year run that only four other all-time greats have done. Russell, Bird, Johnson and James are the only players to win three regular-season MVPs and two NBA titles in a four-year span.", "source": {"uri": "myjoyonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8118240375", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:25:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:25:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:24:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/sport/nba/denver-nuggets-star-nikola-jokic-cements-nba-legacy-with-third-mvp-award-c-14602285", "title": "It's no joke: Jokic cruises to third NBA MVP award", "body": "Denver Nuggets star Nikola Jokic cements NBA legacy with third MVP awardAAPThu, 9 May 2024 8:18AMCommentsComments\n\nNikola Jokic did it all again. And the MVP trophy is his again.\n\nJokic, the Denver Nuggets star from Serbia, was announced Wednesday night as the NBA's Most Valuable Player -- his third time winning the award in the past four seasons, a feat that just six other players in league history have accomplished.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists. Others averaged more in each category -- and Jokic has had better years in each of those categories -- but he was the only player to rank in the NBA's top 10 in points, rebounds and assists per game this season.\n\nJokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates,\" Jokic said on TNT, where the award was announced. \"Without them, I'm nothing. Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches ... I cannot be whoever I am without them.\"\n\nIt likely was not a coincidence that Jokic appeared on television for the award announcement wearing a T-shirt commemorating the life of one of his mentors, Golden State assistant coach Dejan Milojevic, who died earlier this year after a heart attack on a road trip.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that a player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic appeared on all 99 ballots, with 18 second-place votes and two third-place votes. Gilgeous-Alexander also appeared on every ballot, with 15 first-place votes, 40 second-place, 40 third-place, three fourth-place and one fifth-place nod.\n\nDoncic was on all but one ballot and got four first-place votes. Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote on his way to fourth. New York's Jalen Brunson was fifth, followed by Boston's Jayson Tatum, Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis and Phoenix's Kevin Durant.\n\n\"Some people say it's the best player on the best team,\" Jokic said, when asked to define an MVP. \"To me, it's the guy who's the most valuable, the team couldn't play without him.\"\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": "thewest.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "The West Australian"}, "authors": [],
