{"uri": "8118256540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:48:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:48:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:46:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/many-nba-mvps-does-nikola-004005321.html", "title": "How many NBA MVPs does Nikola Jokic have? Denver Nuggets big man picks up third of career", "body": "On Wednesday, before Game 2 of the New York Knicks-Indiana Pacers series in the Eastern Conference semifinals, the Denver Nuggets big man was named the 2024 recipient of the NBA's Most Valuable Player for the third time in his career.\n\n\"Got to start with the teammates. Without them, I cannot do nothing,\" Jokic said on TNT's \"Inside the NBA\" on Wednesday after earning the award. \"So coaches, players, organization, medical staff, development coaches, it's all one big circle. But I cannot be whatever I'm without them.\"\n\nREQUIRED READING: Nuggets' Nikola Jokic wins third NBA MVP award in four seasons\n\nThe nine-year NBA veteran beat out Oklahoma City Thunder point guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander in the voting by a total of 286 votes (64 first-place votes) for the award. The Dallas Mavericks' Luka Donic, Knicks' Jalen Brunson and the Milwaukee Bucks' Giannis Antetokounmpo rounded out the top five in the voting.\n\nJokic is averaging 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and nine assists per game this season. He brings 25 triple-doubles into Thursday's Game 3 against the Minnesota Timberwolves, in which the Nuggets look to avoid going down 3-0.\n\nHere's what you need to know about Jokic's MVP history:\n\nAfter being recognized as the 2024 NBA MVP, Jokic has now won the award three times, including in three of the last four seasons (2021, 2022 and 2024). The only year he did not win it was in 2023, as Philadelphia 76ers forward Joel Embiid won the award.\n\nAs noted by ESPN, \"the Joker\" is the first center since Baketball Hall of Famer Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to win the MVP award three times in a four-year span.\n\nJokic joins an elite class of NBA players with his third award, becoming just the ninth player to win three or more MVP awards in the history of the NBA. He is the first since LeBron James did it in 2012 as a member of the Miami Heat.\n\nHere's the full list of NBA players who have won the MVP award on three or more occasions according to the NBA:", {"uri": "2024-05-349595847", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:45:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:45:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:36:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://kdvr.com/sports/denver-nuggets/denver-nuggets-star-nikola-jokic-wins-third-nba-mvp-award/", "title": "Denver Nuggets star Nikola Jokic wins third NBA MVP award", "body": "DENVER (KDVR) -- Nikola Jokic has done it again. The Denver Nuggets powerhouse was awarded his third NBA Most Valuable Player award on Wednesday, becoming just the ninth player in history to do so.\n\nHis previous MVP awards came in 2021 and 2022. He lost out to Philadelphia 76ers center Joel Embiid in 2023.\n\nThe Nuggets center was up against Oklahoma City Thunder's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and the Dallas Mavericks' Luka Doncic in the race for the best.\n\nJokic was a constant presence on the court throughout the season. He played 79 of the 82 games, averaging 34.6 minutes per game, a career high.\n\nHe averaged 26.4 points per game, the second-highest point average in his career behind the 2021-22 season.\n\n3-time MVP club\n\nWith this, Jokic enters an elite group of NBA players with three or more MVP trophies. Only eight others have done so in the history of the sport.\n\nThree NBA Hall of Famers -- Larry Bird, Magic Johnson and Moses Malone -- have also earned three MVP trophies.\n\nThe last person in the league to break the two-trophy barrier was LeBron James in 2012. The Lakers superstar has four overall, meaning Jokic would need to pick up another one to tie the score.\n\nJokic is also the first person born outside of the U.S. to win the award three or more {"uri": "8118203675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:39:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:39:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:38:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/colorado/news/nba-mvp-nikola-jokic-denver-nuggets-kia-wins-kia-nba-most-valuable-player-third-time/", "title": "Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic wins Kia NBA Most Valuable Player for third time", "body": "The NBA announced on Wednesday that Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic won the NBA Kia MVP for the third time in his career.\n\nAs usual, the Serbian giant has been one of the main focal points for Denver on both ends of the floor along with his co-star Jamal Murray.\n\nNBA critics believe Jokic had a \"strong overall campaign and stellar finish\" out of the other league MVP candidates in OKC's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, Maverick's Luka Doncic, Buck's Giannis Antetokounmpo, and Celtics' Jayson Tatum.\n\nFor the regular season, the now three-time MVP winner nearly averaged a triple-double with 26.4 points per game, 9.0 assists per game and 12.4 rebounds per game in 34.6 minutes played per game. He also shot 58.3% from the field, 35.9% from behind the arc and 81.7% at the free throw line.\n\nFor the postseason through seven games played, he's averaged 28.6 points a game, 15.0 rebounds per game and 9.4 assists per game. Jokic is also shooting 95.1% from the free throw line and is 28.6% from the 3-point line at 40.1 minutes per game in the postseason.\n\nFor his MVP season, Jokic had a list of milestones and broke a few records which include becoming the second player in NBA history to record multiple triple-doubles where they shot 100% from the field, setting the NBA record with seven straight seasons with at least 10 triple-doubles, recording a triple-double against every team and scoring 30 points or more against every NBA opponent.\n\nJokic joins a small list of NBA legends who secured three MVPs with Magic Johnson, Larry Bird and Moses Malone. Only Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (six), Michael Jordan (five), Bill Russell (five), LeBron James (four) and Wilt Chamberlain (four) received more MVP trophies in their careers.\n\nAmong the league, the NBA superstar ranks first in total plus-minutes, second in total assists, third in rebounds and fifth in total points.\n\nJokic is currently in a battle for a second-round playoff victory over a loaded Minnesota Timberwolves who currently lead the series 2-0 against Denver.\n\nThe Nuggets face the T-wolves for Game 3 on Friday on the road at the Target Center with tipoff at 7:30 p.m.", "source": {"uri": "8118339638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:28:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:28:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:28:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.lamarledger.com/2024/05/08/nikola-jokic-nba-mvp-three-time-winner/", "title": "Nuggets' Nikola Jokic named MVP, becomes ninth player in NBA history to win three", "body": "In another season of unpredictably dazzling passes and post moves, the most spontaneous scene of all involved Nikola Jokic simply walking off a basketball court.\n\nIt was January in Washington after a 42-point masterclass against an unimpressive opponent. A throng of Wizards fans flocked to the corner of their arena where Jokic would disappear down the tunnel toward the locker room. The enemy sent him off with an ovation. \"There's a lot of talented players in this league,\" Nuggets coach Michael Malone said afterward, \"but if you don't love Nikola Jokic, I don't know what you're looking for.\"\n\nJokic, 29, was named Most Valuable Player in the NBA for the third time in his career Wednesday night, beating out finalists Luka Doncic (Dallas Mavericks) and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Oklahoma City Thunder) for the 2023-24 prize.\n\nHe is the ninth three-time MVP in league history, joining Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Bill Russell, Michael Jordan, Wilt Chamberlain, LeBron James, Magic Johnson, Larry Bird and Moses Malone. Only seven players have won the award three times in a four-year stretch.\n\n\"When I won the first time, I was like, 'OK, this is cool. This is nice.' When I won the second time, the list was way shorter,\" Jokic said. \"And now the list is kind of short short. So I'm just happy to be part of that group of guys, which is not a bad group of guys, right? ... It's a legacy for after the career, and I think I'm gonna be more, maybe, proud of myself after my career than I am right now.\"\n\nJokic earned 79 of 99 first-place votes in a runaway victory. He was followed by Gilgeous-Alexander (15 first-place votes), Doncic (4) and Giannis Antetokounmpo (1). Voters rank their top five. The lowest Jokic finished on anyone's ballot was third place. He amassed 926 points. Gilgeous-Alexander was the runner-up with 640 points.\n\nSince the implementation of a media voting panel in 1980-81, only three players have finished top-two in MVP voting four consecutive years: Bird, Tim Duncan and now Jokic. Russell and Abdul-Jabbar accomplished the feat under the old voting system.\n\nJokic finished the regular season ranked fifth in total points, third in total rebounds and second in total assists -- top-five in all three categories for the second time in his career. He averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and nine assists per game, compiling 25 triple-doubles and shooting 58.3% from the field. His true shooting percentage eclipsed 65% for the third consecutive season.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" longtime teammate Jamal Murray said Wednesday before the award was announced amid an awkward backdrop: Denver trailing a playoff series 2-0. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every day. He does it in the smallest ways. He makes everybody around us better. He's a leader on the court and someone we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court. And he's delivered. ... He's been so consistent all his career, all his MVP runs. He's been so consistent. So I don't expect one or two bad games to sway that in any way.\"\n\nWhen Jokic was on the court this season, the Nuggets outscored their opponents by 11.8 points per 100 possessions. When he was off the court, they were outscored by 8.6 points per 100 possessions, amounting to a 20.4-point difference in net rating. Denver's 122.4 offensive rating with Jokic on the floor was more efficient than the best offensive team in the league, the Celtics (122.2). Denver's 104.1 offensive rating without Jokic was lower than the worst offensive team in the league, the Grizzlies (106.8).\n\nThe Nuggets finished in a tie for the best record in the Western Conference. Their 57-25 regular season tied a franchise wins record. Jokic is the team's only starter who has been named an All-Star in his career.\n\nHe averaged 101.3 touches per game, nearly 10 more than any other individual in the league, and 75.1 passes per game, 3.5 more than any other player. He led the NBA in most advanced metrics including player efficiency rating (31.0), win shares (17.0), win shares per 48 minutes (.299), offensive box plus/minus (9.0), defensive box plus/minus (4.2) and value over a replacement player (10.6).\n\n\"To be honest, I liked last year when I didn't get it and then we won a championship. Much better,\" Jokic said. \"But I don't know what to say. It's a journey. It's a process. It's trusting your teammates; teammates trusting you. It's just a whole collective effort that put me in front of, like, the bright spotlight.\"\n\nJokic's first two MVPs were bestowed before he had won a championship, or even reached the NBA Finals. Each was accompanied, therefore, by a fair degree of scrutiny. He didn't have the winning reputation to correspond with his individual accolades.\n\nThat's different this time. Jokic owns a Finals MVP trophy. A month before the startling round of applause he received in Washington, another unusual scene paralleled it, speaking volumes about the growth of Jokic's eminence outside Denver. It was Dec. 12 in Chicago, and for the second time in three weeks, Jokic had just been tossed from a game after arguing with referees.\n\nThis time, as he sauntered toward the locker room to serve his sentence, the crowd started booing. Not at Jokic. At the officials. Only one technical foul prompted the ejection. Disappointment and disgust permeated through United Center as Bulls fans watched the reason they'd purchased their tickets disappear for the night.", "source": {"uri": "lamarledger.com", "dataType": Oklahoma City guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (15 first-place votes, 640 points) was second and Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic (4, 566) was third.\n\nJokic averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists in 79 games this season. He had 25 triple-doubles, second in the league behind Domantas Sabonis (26) of the Sacramento Kings.\n\nLast season, Jokic was the runner-up behind Joel Embiid of the Philadelphia 76ers. Jokic won the award in the 2020-21 and 2021-22 seasons.\n\nKareem Abdul-Jabbar holds the record of six MVP awards. Michael Jordan and Bill Russell won it five times, while Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James each won four.\n\nJokic is tied with Larry Bird, Magic Johnson and Moses Malone as three-time winners.\n\nMilwaukee Bucks forward Giannis Antetokounmpo (one, 192) finished fourth in this season's balloting and New York Knicks guard Jalen Brunson (142) was fifth.", "source": {"uri": "https://i.kinja-img.com/image/upload/c_fill,h_675,pg_1,q_80,w_1200/015df44bd0430e1b5af93c5422bb3d62.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": {"uri": "8118262293", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:54:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:54:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:54:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/sports/inside-the-nba-mvp-race-jokics-consistency-was-key-and-no-1-picks-were-denied/article_59259d39-549f-50a4-a8e5-95c22de6ff44.html", "title": "Inside the NBA MVP Race: Jokic's consistency was key, and No. 1 picks were denied the trophy again", "body": "Oklahoma City Thunder guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (2) talks with official Tony Brothers during the second half of Game 1 of an NBA basketball second-round playoff series against the Dallas Mavericks, Tuesday, May 7, 2024, in Oklahoma City.\n\nA look at some notes and numbers surrounding the NBA's MVP race this season:\n\nMULTIPLE TOP 10s\n\nDenver's Nikola Jokic was the only player in the league to rank among the top 10 in points (10th), rebounds (4th) and assists (3rd) per game this season, which surely went a long way toward voters giving him the MVP award for the third time in four years.\n\nThere were only three other players who ranked among top 10 in two of those categories.\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic won the scoring title and was second in assists per game. Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo was second in points and sixth in rebounds per game, and Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis led the league in rebounds per game while ranking sixth in assists per contest.\n\nTOP PICK DROUGHT\n\nThere's a reasonable chance that Victor Wembanyama -- the No. 1 pick in last year's draft by San Antonio, along with the rookie of the year winner and runner-up to Minnesota's Rudy Gobert for defensive player of the year this season -- wins the MVP award one day.\n\nBut Nikola Jokic's win this year extended an unusual streak.\n\nFor the 11th straight year, the MVP award was claimed by someone who wasn't a No. 1 overall draft pick. That's the longest such run in NBA history; the last No. 1 to win was LeBron James, then of Miami, in 2013.\n\nFINISHING TOP 2\n\nNikola Jokic is the fifth player in NBA history to finish first or second in the MVP balloting in at least four consecutive seasons. He won the award in 2021, 2022 and this year, and was second to Philadelphia's Joel Embiid in 2023.\n\nBoston Celtics greats Bill Russell and Larry Bird each were first or second in the balloting in six consecutive seasons. Russell won in 1958, 1961, 1962 and 1963, while finishing second in 1959 and 1960; Bird was second in 1981, 1982 and 1983 before winning in 1984, 1985 and 1986.\n\nKareem Abdul-Jabbar (1971-74) and Tim Duncan (2001-04) are the other players with four straight top-two finishes.\n\n33, 9 AND 9 NOT ENOUGH\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic averaged 33.9 points, 9.2 rebounds and 9.8 assists per game this season. There had never been a season in NBA history in which someone finished with all those averages.\n\nAnd he still didn't win MVP.\n\nThere were 14 previous instances of someone averaging at least 33 points and nine rebounds; those stats were enough to MVP five times (Joel Embiid in 2023, Bob McAdoo in 1975, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar in 1972, Wilt Chamberlain in 1960 and 1966).\n\nOf course, it should be noted that Chamberlain had some years when he was even more dominant and didn't win MVP -- including five consecutive seasons in which he averaged at least 34 points and 22 rebounds but didn't get the trophy in any of them. Elgin Baylor averaged at least 34 points and 14 rebounds in three seasons when he wasn't MVP, and Rick Barry had a 35.6-point, 9.2-rebound year that didn't get him the award, either.\n\nBefore Doncic this year, there was just one season in which a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists. That was 1972-73 when Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11.4 assists for Kansas City. He was third in the MVP voting that season.\n\nREACHING HEIGHTS\n\nNikola Jokic's win means a player who is listed at 6-foot-10 or taller -- Giannis Antetokounmpo in 2019 and 2020, Jokic in 2021, 2022 and now 2024, and Joel Embiid in 2023 -- has won the MVP award in six consecutive seasons.\n\nThat's a first for the NBA. But that doesn't mean this is the first dominant stretch for big men. Far from it.\n\nThere was a 16-year stretch from 1964-65 through 1979-80 when players generally considered to be centers or at least power forwards won the award each year. Not all were at least 6-10, but all were considered big men.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nThe last guard to win the MVP award was James Harden, then of Houston, in 2018.\n\nGIANNIS' STREAK\n\nMilwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote. It mattered.\n\nAntetokounmpo has now gotten at least one first-place MVP vote in six consecutive seasons, extending the longest such streak in the league.\n\nIt's the longest first-place-vote streak since LeBron James got a first-place vote in eight consecutive years from 2008 through 2015. That run ended when Golden State's Stephen Curry became the first -- and still only -- unanimous MVP in 2016.\n\nDenver's Nikola Jokic has gotten a first-place vote in each of the last four years. Philadelphia's Joel Embiid had first-place votes in each of the previous three seasons but was ineligible for consideration this year because of the league's new rule mandating that players must appear in a certain number of games before getting onto the ballot.\n\nNO LeBRON\n\nLeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers didn't get a vote in the MVP balloting this season. It's only the second time in his 21-year career that has happened; the other was last season, ending an unprecedented 19-year streak of getting at least one vote. (The panel of reporters and broadcasters who vote on awards rank their top five MVP choices on their ballots.)\n\nHe is the only player in NBA history to appear in the MVP results in 19 different seasons. When the All-NBA team is revealed later this month, James could make a 20th appearance, which would extend his record.\n\nNo other player has more than 15 All-NBA nods.\n\nALL THE AWARDS\n\nHere's a wrapup of all the NBA awards that have been announced to this point:\n\n-- Most Valuable Player, Nikola Jokic, Denver.\n\n-- Most Improved Player, Tyrese Maxey, Philadelphia.\n\n-- Rookie of the Year, Victor Wembanyama, San Antonio.\n\n-- Defensive Player of the Year, Rudy Gobert, Minnesota.\n\n-- Sixth Man of the Year, Naz Reid, Minnesota.\n\n-- Clutch Player of the Year, Stephen Curry, Golden State.\n\n-- Coach of the Year, Mark Daigneault, Oklahoma City.\n\n-- Twyman-Stokes Teammate of the Year, Mike Conley, Minnesota.\n\n-- Executive of the Year, Brad Stevens, Boston.\n\nAP NBA: {"uri": "2024-05-350028736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:37:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:37:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:55:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1145176/nikola-jokic-mvp-x-3-at-nba", "title": "Nikola Jokic, third-time MVP at NBA", "body": "Serbian centre Nikola Jokic of the Denver Nuggets has been named the NBA's Most Valuable Player for the third time in the last four seasons in the world's top basketball league.\n\nThe Serbian pivot of the NBA, Nikola Jokic, achieves a new title as the NBA's Most Valuable Player, emulating what he achieved in 2021 and 2022, always with the NBA's Denver Nuggets.\n\nThe 29-year-old Serbian star, who has been in great form over the past five years, not only won the regular season Most Valuable Player award in 2021 and 2022, but also finished second in the voting in 2023, a year in which he paradoxically won the championship but had the satisfaction of leading the Nuggets to their first NBA title.\n\nThat season, he averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists in the regular season, beating Oklahoma City Thunder star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and fellow Balkan Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks in the final voting for the award.\n\nIn an increasingly globalised league with contributions from international players, it is not insignificant that the top three players were not born in the United States, something unthinkable 20 years ago and which should draw attention to those who run the world's most important league. Only Shai Gilgeous-Alexander is North American, but not American (he was born in Toronto, Canada).\n\nJokic's victory also marks the sixth consecutive season that the MVP award has gone to a player born outside the United States. The last American-born player to win the award was James Harden in 2018.\n\nThe 2.11-metre centre, who was born on 19 February 1995 in Sombor, Serbia, managed to make brilliance look routine, becoming only the second player after Oscar Robertson to record 2,000 points, 900 rebounds and 600 assists in a season.\n\nThe fact that Colorado finished with the second-best record of all 30 NBA teams (57-25, behind only the Celtics' 64-18 and tied with the Thunder) was crucial. His 25 triple-doubles and 68 double-doubles speak for themselves.\n\nJokic enters elite territory with his third regular-season MVP crown. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's six MVPs are the most ever. Bill Russell andMichael Jordan each won five, while Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James are ahead of the Serb, who still has plenty of years ahead of him.\n\n\"You have to start with your teammates. I can't do anything without them,\" Jokic said during the MVP announcement on TNT when asked to reflect on another MVP.\n\n\"Coaches, players, organization, medical staff, developmental coaches over time, it's all a big circle that I couldn't be where I am without them.\n\nAs always, the MVP award was a controversial one. Canadian Gilgeous-Alexander averaged 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds, 6.2 assists and 2.0 steals per game for Oklahoma City and had 51 games of at least 30 points, the most in the league.\n\nSlovenian Luka Doncic, a former Real Madrid player, led the league in scoring with 33.9 points per game and was second in assists with 9.8 per game. He averaged 9.2 rebounds per game and became the third player to average a 30-point triple-double after the All-Star break, joining Oscar Robertson (1961-62) and Russell Westbrook (2016-17).\n\nHowever, Nuggets coach Mike Malone had no doubt that Jokic deserved his third MVP. \"When he gets up in the morning... he's not doing it for the individual accolades and recognition,\" Malone said. \"He does it for the collective to win and hopefully win another championship. That's what it's all about.\"\n\nAwards aside, Tuesday's loss means the Nuggets have lost the first two games of their Western Conference semifinal series against the Minnesota Timberwolves and face the daunting task of trying to bounce back on the road starting on Friday.", "source": {"uri": "insidethegames.biz", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.insidethegames.biz"}, "authors": [{"uri": This stirred a controversial debate since many believed other stars like Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Luka Doncic deserved the trophy.\n\nJokic finally came out and spoke on winning the award, sharing an incredibly humble response to winning his third league MVP.\n\n\"To be honest. I liked last year when I didn't win it and we won a championship much better,\" said Jokic, via Sideline Sources on Instagram.\n\nThis truly shows Jokic's modest attitude with a team-first mentality. The Nuggets were able to go all the way in the 2023 season, winning the NBA title behind Jokic and company.\n\nJokic has never been a player that attempts to take over the spotlight. He's fine with basketball being his day job, and keeping the rest of his life private.\n\nHe's a generational player, but the bright lights don't benefit Jokic. Denver's star has one goal in mind each season, and that's to win an NBA championship.\n\nRelated: Shaquille O'Neal Sends Five-Word Message To NBA MVP Nikola Jokic\n\nRelated: Everyone's Saying The {"uri": "8118659294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:21:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:21:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:21:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/basketball/denver-nuggets-nikola-jokic-scoops-third-nba-most-valuable-player-award", "title": "Denver Nuggets' Nikola Jokic scoops third NBA Most Valuable Player award", "body": "LOS ANGELES - Nikola Jokic thanked his \"one big circle\" at the Denver Nuggets after he was named National Basketball Association (NBA) Most Valuable Player for the third time in four seasons on May 8.\n\nThe 29-year-old Serbian star, who won the award in 2021 and 2022, finished runner-up in the voting in 2023 to Joel Embiid of the Philadelphia 76ers but had the satisfaction of leading the Nuggets to a first NBA title.\n\nThis season he averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists in the regular season and beat out Oklahoma City Thunder star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks in final voting for the award.\n\n\"We've got to start with the teammates. Without them I cannot do anything,\" Jokic said in the MVP announcement broadcast on TNT when asked to reflect on yet another MVP.\n\n\"Coaches, players, organisation, medical staff, across time coaches, development coaches - it's all one big circle that I cannot be wherever I am without them.\"\n\nIn another season in which he managed to make brilliance almost look routine, he became the second player, after Oscar Robertson, to record 2,000 points, 900 rebounds and 600 assists in a season.\n\nHis 25 triple-doubles and 68 double-doubles were both second in the league to the Sacramento Kings' Domantas Sabonis (26 and 77 respectively).\n\nWith a third MVP crown, Jokic also enters elite territory.\n\nKareem Abdul-Jabbar's six MVPs are the most ever. Bill Russell and Michael Jordan won five apiece and Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James four.\n\nJokic joins Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson as three-time winners after earning 79 first-placed votes compared to 15 for Gilgeous-Alexander and four for Doncic.\n\nAs always, the MVP award offered plenty of scope for argument.\n\nBut Jokic was not offended during the TNT interview when it was suggested that Gilgeous-Alexander might have been a more worthy winner.\n\n\"There are a lot of players who deserve it,\" he said. \"It's probably the details and the small things.\"\n\nGilgeous-Alexander, a 25-year-old Canadian, averaged 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds, 6.2 assists and 2.0 steals per game for upstarts Oklahoma City and had a league-high 51 30-point games.\n\nSlovenia's Doncic led the league in scoring with 33.9 points per game and ranked second in assists with 9.8 per game, behind the Indiana Pacers' Tyrese Haliburton (10.9).\n\nBut Nuggets coach Mike Malone was in no doubt that Jokic's third MVP was richly deserved.\n\n\"I don't know if I can put that into words what his greatness means,\" he said.\n\n\"When he gets up in the morning... he's not doing it for the individual accolades and recognition. He's doing it for the collective to win and hopefully win another championship. That's what he's all about.\n\n\"That is what I marvel at. Just the consistent greatness and how he finds ways to every single night, no matter who is available around him, to bring that level of excellence.\"\n\nThe Nuggets, meanwhile, dropped the first two games of their Western Conference semi-final series to the Minnesota Timberwolves, and face the tough task of trying to claw back on the Timberwolves' home court starting on May 10. Bill Russell and Michael Jordan won five apiece and Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James four.\n\nMore from this section NY: ACE Awards 2024 - Arrivals - 53059654 Security camera footage shows onset of deadly Stamford house fire Democrats rescue Republican US House speaker from right wing rebellion\n\nJokic joins Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson as three-time winners after earning 79 first-placed votes compared to 15 for Gilgeous-Alexander and four for Doncic.\n\nBehind Jokic, the 57-25 Nuggets matched the franchise high for victories in a season -- although they were tied for best record in the West with Oklahoma City and ended up with the second seed.\n\nWhether Jokic will be able to combine an MVP award and the title this season remains to be seen.\n\nThe Nuggets dropped the first two games of their Western Conference semi-final series to the Minnesota Timberwolves and face the tough task of trying to claw back on the Timberwolves' home court starting on Friday.\n\nJokic's victory marks the sixth straight season that the MVP award has gone to a player born outside the United States. {"uri": "8115875455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:51:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:51:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:50:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.totalprosports.com/nba/mvp-has-never-went-to-the-best-player-charles-barkley-throws-shades-on-mvp-voting-process-predicts-close-contest-this-season/", "title": "\"MVP Has Never Went to the Best Player\": Charles Barkley Throws Shades on MVP Voting Process, Predicts Close Contest This Season", "body": "The NBA MVP has always been a topic of extreme scrutiny. With different opinions comes different criteria for winning the prestigious award. Charles Barkley, the winner of the 1993 NBA MVP award, also has his views on it, which he candidly discussed just like he does about all things related to basketball.\n\nOn a recent episode of Shannon Sharpe's Club Shay Shay podcast, the former Sixers forward revealed his distaste for the MVP selection process. \"The MVP has never went to the best player. Never. It goes to the best player on the best team,\" said Chuck. He further added, \"Because nobody in their right mind thinks Steve Nash is better than Shaq and Kobe [Bryant].\"\n\nOn the flip side, Sir Charles also praised some instances where he believed the deserving candidate won the award. In 2011, Derrick Rose won the NBA MVP over LeBron James and, to Barkley, that was fair because of the Bulls' 62-20 record. He also discussed the candidates for this season and delivered his verdict on the 2024 NBA MVP race.\n\nThis year's NBA MVP race was one for the ages. After the reigning MVP, Joel Embiid was deemed ineligible due to his injury and the 65-game rule, Nikola Jokic remained in the pole position to earn a third MVP award. Luka Doncic and Shai-Gilgeous Alexander are also in the mix. But according to Charles Barkley, Jalen Brunson is the one he backs for the Michael Jordan trophy.\n\n\"What Brunson did this year for the Knicks was incredible, to get them to the second seed without Robinson being out for most of the year, without Randle [out] most of the year, OG [Anunoby] was out for a period of time,\" said Barkley.\n\nHe added that his and Magic Johnson's race in the 1990 NBA MVP race was close, but this year will be the closest one ever. {"uri": "8119369250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:11:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:11:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:10:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/nba/news/shai-gilgeous-alexander-nikola-jokic-stats-mvp/1df4e6060c9ca41e1f767c47", "title": "Shai Gilgeous-Alexander vs. Nikola Jokic stats: Why didn't SGA win MVP for historic Thunder season?", "body": "To the surprise of few, Nuggets superstar Nikola Jokic ran away with his third MVP award for his efforts during the 2023-24 NBA season. And while few were surprised, many were upset that Thunder star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander did not receive the honor.\n\nHall of Famer Shaquille O'Neal was among the first to express his displeasure with Gilgeous-Alexander missing out on the award, and many basketball fans on social media soon followed.\n\nBased on precedent, O'Neal and the fans on social media have a right to be displeased.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander led the Thunder to a 57-25 record and the West's No. 1 seed while averaging 30.1 points and turning in a franchise-record 51 games with 30-plus points. The 25-year-old is the first player since 1967 to average 30-plus points per game on the West's top seed and not win MVP, per StatMamba.\n\nWith Gilgeous-Alexander's case in mind, it's important to note that Jokic led Denver to an identical 57-25 record with impressive averages, eye-popping advanced stats and 25 triple-doubles during the 2023-24 season.\n\nAs each star put together a compelling case to win the award, here's how their numbers and MVP cases measure up.\n\nMORE: Complete list of winners for NBA's end-of-season awards\n\nBased on counting stats, Gilgeous-Alexander gets the edge in scoring and steals while Jokic averaged more rebounds and assists on slightly more efficient shooting splits.\n\nBoth players were largely available throughout the 2023-24 season, which shows their value to their respective teams.\n\nTo get more granular, Jokic has the edge on Gilgeous-Alexander in the advanced stats realm. Given how close many of the counting stats were, Jokic was able to create some separation with his advanced numbers.\n\nMORE: Where Nikola Jokic's three MVP awards rank on all-time list\n\nDenver went 2-1 without Jokic during the 2023-24 NBA season. The Nuggets were 55-24 with their MVP in the lineup.\n\nJokic was almost always available for his team during the regular season, missing just three of 82 games. He did not miss consecutive games.\n\nDenver's lone loss without Jokic came against the Thunder on Jan. 31. Behind 34 points from Gilgeous-Alexander, OKC earned a five-point home win over Denver.\n\nOklahoma City was 2-5 without Gilgeous-Alexander during the 2023-24 season. The Thunder were 55-20 when SGA was available.\n\nSix of Gilgeous-Alexander's seven absences came toward the end of the season as he battled a quad injury. He appeared in 70 of the team's first 71 games before sitting out six out of seven games between March 27 and April 7.\n\nOklahoma City's wins without Gilgeous-Alexander came at home against Phoenix and on the road against Charlotte.\n\nMORE: Why Shaq said SGA deserved 2024 NBA MVP over Nikola Jokic\n\nGilgeous-Alexander finished second to Jokic in 2024 NBA MVP award voting.\n\nJokic received 79 of 99 possible first-place votes while Gilgeous-Alexander received 15 first-place votes. Luka Doncic (four) and Giannis Antetokounmpo (one) were the only other players to receive first-place votes.\n\nHere is a look at how MVP voting shook out based on first-place votes:\n\nSecond-place votes are worth seven points, third-place votes are worth five points, fourth-place votes are worth three points and fifth-place votes are worth one point.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", {"uri": "8118217964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:57:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:57:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:56:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://chatnewstoday.ca/2024/05/08/jokic-wins-nbas-mvp-award-his-3rd-in-4-seasons-gilgeous-alexander-and-doncic-round-out-top-3/", "title": "Jokic wins NBA's MVP award, his 3rd in 4 seasons. Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic round out top 3", "body": "Jokic got 79 of a possible 99 first-place votes from the panel of reporters and broadcasters who cast ballots on awards when the regular season ended.\n\nOklahoma City's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was second and Dallas' Luka Doncic was third, both getting into the top three of MVP voting for the first time. With Jokic from Serbia, Gilgeous-Alexander from Canada and Doncic from Slovenia, it marked the third consecutive season that three players born outside the U.S. finished 1-2-3 in the MVP balloting.\n\nThis time, the foreign dominance atop the NBA was even more pronounced: Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo, who is from Greece, was fourth -- so this became the first time in the award's 69-year history that international players went 1-2-3-4 in the voting. It also became the sixth consecutive year that an player born outside the U.S. won the award.\n\nJokic is now the ninth player to win the MVP award at least three times. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won it six times, Bill Russell and Michael Jordan each won five, Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won four, and Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson are the other three-time winners.\n\nJokic's surprise rise to superstardom has been chronicled time and again over the years: He was the 41st overall pick in the 2014 draft, didn't even think he had a realistic chance at playing in the NBA when his career was beginning and now has a Hall of Fame resume at 29.\n\nThe other players with three MVP trophies in a four-year span are James, Johnson, Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Chamberlain and Russell. And Jokic becomes the fifth player to be first or second in the MVP voting in four consecutive years -- joining Bird, Abdul-Jabbar, Russell and Tim Duncan.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander had perhaps the best feel-good story in the NBA this season, helping Oklahoma City to the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference by averaging 30.1 points, 5.5 rebounds and 6.2 assists. The Thunder won 57 games, 17 more than they did last season and 33 more than they did two years ago, their rise coinciding with Gilgeous-Alexander's emergence as one of the game's elite players.\n\n\"There is not a night when I don't feel like we have the best player on the floor. ... There's no one I'd rather have on our team than him,\" Thunder coach Mark Daigneault, the league's coach of the year this season, said last month.\n\nDoncic made a case for the MVP award by posting the first season in NBA history in which a player averaged 34 points, nine rebounds and nine assists per game. There had been 14 instances before this year in which a player averaged that many points and rebounds in a season -- of those, five had resulted in MVP wins, including last season when Philadelphia's Joel Embiid averaged 33 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nAnd this was the second time ever that a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists per game. The other was in 1972-73, when Kansas City's Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11 assists. He finished third in that season's MVP voting, just like Doncic did this season.", "source": {"uri": "chatnewstoday.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CHAT News Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shai_Gilgeous-Alexander", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Shai Gilgeous-Alexander"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikola_Joki\u0107", {"uri": "8118251687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:40:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:40:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:40:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://sportsnaut.com/nikola-jokic-nba-mvp-shaquille-oneal/", "title": "Shaquille O'Neal called out for telling Nikola Jokic he shouldn't have won NBA MVP", "body": "Denver Nuggets star center Nikola Jokic was surprisingly named the NBA MVP for the 2023-24 season on Wednesday.\n\nJokic beat out the likes of Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, Luka Doncic, Giannis Antetokounmpo and Jalen Brunson for the Association's top individual award.\n\nJokic received 79 of the 100 first-place votes to win going away. This represents his third NBA MVP award of the past four seasons.\n\nAn argument can be made that Jokic deserved the award less than a calendar year after leading Denver to the NBA title.\n\nThis came on a Nuggets team that won 57 regular-season games. Sure, Jokic is deserving. But there are others who believe SGA should have come away with it.\n\nRelated: Nikola Jokic and the best NBA players of 2024\n\nAhead of the Indiana Pacers and New York Knicks playoff game on TNT Wednesday evening, the pre-game show had Jokic on. Shaq confronted the game's best big by telling him Shai Gilgeous-Alexander should have won.\n\n\"You know I love you. You're the best player in the league. I want to congratulate you. But I want you to hear it from me first, I thought that SGA should have been the MVP. That's no disrespect to you,\" Shaq told Jokic.\n\nThat's not necessarily a good look from Shaq. He should have kept this conversation private. Jokic was celebrating a huge honor. {"uri": "8118201887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:37:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:37:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:36:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.denverpost.com/2024/05/08/nikola-jokic-nba-mvp-three-time-winner/", "title": "Nuggets' Nikola Jokic named MVP, becomes ninth player in NBA history to win three", "body": "In another season of unpredictably dazzling passes and post moves, the most spontaneous scene of all involved Nikola Jokic simply walking off a basketball court.\n\nIt was January in Washington after a 42-point masterclass against an unimpressive opponent. A throng of Wizards fans flocked to the corner of their arena where Jokic would disappear down the tunnel toward the locker room. The enemy sent him off with an ovation. \"There's a lot of talented players in this league,\" Nuggets coach Michael Malone said afterward, \"but if you don't love Nikola Jokic, I don't know what you're looking for.\"\n\nJokic, 29, was named Most Valuable Player in the NBA for the third time in his career Wednesday night, beating out finalists Luka Doncic (Dallas Mavericks) and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Oklahoma City Thunder) for the 2023-24 prize.\n\nHe is the ninth three-time MVP in league history, joining Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Bill Russell, Michael Jordan, Wilt Chamberlain, LeBron James, Magic Johnson, Larry Bird and Moses Malone. Only seven players have won the award three times in a four-year stretch.\n\nSince the implementation of a media voting panel in 1980-81, only three players have finished top-two in MVP voting four consecutive years: Bird, Tim Duncan and now Jokic. Russell and Abdul-Jabbar accomplished the feat under the old voting system.\n\nJokic finished the regular season ranked fifth in total points, third in total rebounds and second in total assists -- top-five in all three categories for the second time in his career. He averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and nine assists per game, compiling 25 triple-doubles and shooting 58.3% from the field. His true shooting percentage eclipsed 65% for the third consecutive season.\n\n\"I think he's stated his case pretty well,\" longtime teammate Jamal Murray said Wednesday before the award was announced amid an awkward backdrop: Denver trailing a playoff series 2-0. \"He does it every night. It's hard to do what he does and face the kind of pressure that he does each and every day. He does it in the smallest ways. He makes everybody around us better. He's a leader on the court and someone we expect greatness from every time he steps on the court. And he's delivered. ... He's been so consistent all his career, all his MVP runs. He's been so consistent. So I don't expect one or two bad games to sway that in any way.\"\n\nWhen Jokic was on the court this season, the Nuggets outscored their opponents by 11.8 points per 100 possessions. When he was off the court, they were outscored by 8.6 points per 100 possessions, amounting to a 20.4-point difference in net rating. Denver's 122.4 offensive rating with Jokic on the floor was more efficient than the best offensive team in the league, the Celtics (122.2). Denver's 104.1 offensive rating without Jokic was lower than the worst offensive team in the league, the Grizzlies (106.8).\n\nThe Nuggets finished in a tie for the best record in the Western Conference. Their 57-25 regular season tied a franchise wins record. Jokic is the team's only starter who has been named an All-Star in his career.\n\nHe averaged 101.3 touches per game, nearly 10 more than any other individual in the league, and 75.1 passes per game, 3.5 more than any other player. He led the NBA in most advanced metrics including player efficiency rating (31.0), win shares (17.0), win shares per 48 minutes (.299), offensive box plus/minus (9.0), defensive box plus/minus (4.2) and value over a replacement player (10.6).\n\n\"What I marvel at most importantly with Nikola the player is just the consistent greatness,\" Malone said during the last week of the regular season, when he predicted Jokic would win the MVP again. \"How he finds ways to, every single night, no matter who's available around him, to bring that level of excellence every night and basically put that team on his back.\"\n\nJokic's first two MVPs were bestowed before he had won a championship, or even reached the NBA Finals. Each was accompanied, therefore, by a fair degree of scrutiny. He didn't have the winning reputation to correspond with his individual accolades.\n\nThat's different this time. Jokic owns a Finals MVP trophy. A month before the startling round of applause he received in Washington, another unusual scene paralleled it, speaking volumes about the growth of Jokic's eminence outside Denver. It was Dec. 12 in Chicago, and for the second time in three weeks, Jokic had just been tossed from a game after arguing with referees.\n\nThis time, as he sauntered toward the locker room to serve his sentence, the crowd started booing. Not at Jokic. At the officials. Only one technical foul prompted the ejection. Disappointment and disgust permeated through United Center as Bulls fans watched the reason they'd purchased their tickets disappear for the night.", "source": {"uri": "denverpost.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8118347335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:38:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:38:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:38:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/basketball/nikola-jokic-wins-mvp-for-third-time-denver-nuggets-nominees-nba-latest-news-updates/article68156089.ece", "title": "NBA: Nuggets star Nikola Jokic wins MVP for third time in four seasons", "body": "Denver Nuggets star centre Nikola Jokic was named NBA Most Valuable Player on Wednesday, marking the third time in four seasons that he won the award.\n\nJokic is the ninth player to win the award three or more times.\n\nJokic received 79 first-place votes and totalled 926 points in balloting performed by a group of sportswriters and broadcasters. Oklahoma City guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (15 first-place votes, 640 points) was second, and Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic (4, 566) was third.\n\nJokic averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds, and 9.0 assists in 79 games this season. He had 25 triple-doubles, second in the league behind Domantas Sabonis (26) of the Sacramento Kings.\n\n\"It's got to start with your teammates, you know,\" Jokic said on TNT. \"Without them, I cannot do nothing. Coaches, players, organizations, medical staff, strength coaches, development coaches. It's all one big circle, but I cannot be whatever I am without them.\"\n\nALSO READ: Rudy Gobert named 2024 NBA Defensive Player of the Year\n\nLast season, Jokic was the runner-up behind Joel Embiid of the Philadelphia 76ers. Jokic won the award in the 2020-21 and 2021-22 seasons.\n\nKareem Abdul-Jabbar holds the record of six MVP awards. Michael Jordan and Bill Russell won it five times, while Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James each won four.\n\nJokic is tied with Larry Bird, Magic Johnson and Moses Malone as three-time winners.\n\nThough Jokic won the award comfortably, he wasn't offended when it was suggested that Gilgeous-Alexander might have been a more worthy winner.\n\n\"There are a lot of players who deserve it,\" Jokic said. \"It's probably the details and the small things.\"\n\nJokic led the Nuggets to the NBA title last season and helped Denver compile a 57-25 record in the 2023-24 regular season.\n\nThe Nuggets beat the Los Angeles Lakers in five games in the Western Conference first round but now are facing a tough situation after losing the first two games against the Minnesota Timberwolves in the second round. The series now shifts to Minneapolis for the next two games.\n\n\"Tomorrow, we leave and go to Minnesota and try to get the series back to Denver,\" Jokic said.\n\nMilwaukee Bucks forward Giannis Antetokounmpo (one, 192) finished fourth in this season's balloting, and New York Knicks guard Jalen Brunson (142) was fifth.\n\nLatest on SportstarNBA: Nuggets star Nikola Jokic wins MVP for third {"uri": "2024-05-349657934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:58:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:58:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:36:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/nuggets-news-video-captures-heartwarming-moment-nikola-jokic-learned-of-third-mvp-win", "title": "Video captures heartwarming moment Nikola Jokic learned of third MVP win", "body": "The Denver Nuggets currently find themselves in an unenviable position as they trail their Western Conference Semifinal series against the Minnesota Timberwolves, 0-2. Not only that, but they lost both games at home and now face the daunting prospect of must win games on the road. But prior to Game 3 tipoff, the Nuggets received good news when it was announced that Nikola Jokic had won his third MVP Award. Video caught the moment when Jokic found out the news and it he celebrated the award in true Jokic fashion.\n\nJokic, who has famously endeared himself among NBA fans for not getting very hyped about much, reacted to the MVP news wit ha simple grin and a fist bump in the air while among family and team staff. His one word answer to the win: 'excited.'\n\nJokic won his first MVP award during the 2021-22 season. He followed that up with back to back wins during the 2022-23 season. Ever since the Nuggets were eliminated in the Western Conference Finals during the 2020 playoffs, Jokic has been on a tear.\n\nJokic finished with 79 first place votes for MVP. He was followed by Oklahoma City Thunder star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander who finished second and Dallas Mavericks star Luka Doncic who finished third. The top five was rounded out by Milwaukee Bucks star Giannis Antetokoumpo and New York Knicks star Jalen Brunson.\n\nNikola Jokic cementing himself as Nuggets GOAT\n\nThe Nuggets have had a few Hall of Fame caliber players suit up for the franchise such as David Thompson, Alex English, Carmelo Anthony, Dan Issel, Dikembe Mutombo and Fat Lever to name a few. But when it's all said and done, Nikola Jokic will go down as the greatest player to ever play for the Nuggets.\n\nThe main thing Jokic has going for him is that he is the only star that brought the Nuggets a championship. Prior to last season, the Nuggets had never even appeared in the NBA Finals. During the 2022-23 playoff run, Jokic averaged 30.0 points per game, 13.5 rebounds, 9.5 assists, 1.1 steals and 1.0 blocked shots with splits of 54.8 percent shooting from the field, a playoff career high 46.1 percent shooting from the three point line and 79.9 percent shooting from the free throw line.\n\nDuring the past couple of seasons, Jokic has also etched his name in the NBA history books by matching or surpassing a few records that were held by the late Wilt Chamberlain.\n\nAnd now, Jokic can truly prove his greatness if he is able to lead the Nuggets out of this 0-2 hole the currently find themselves in. During the 2024 playoffs so far, Jokic has been averaging 27.0 points per game, 15.0 rebounds, 9.4 assists and 1.3 steals with splits of 54.2 percent shooting from the field, 28.6 percent shooting from the three point line and a playoff career high 95.1 percent shooting from the free throw line.\n\nJokic has been named to six consecutive All-Star appearances now and that number will only continue to grow as he is in the prime of his career. {"uri": "2024-05-349633605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:07:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:07:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:58:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/nuggets-jokic-scoops-third-nba-most-valuable-player-award/article_4f00f31b-61bd-5bb6-aa36-4f03ccd99c70.html", "title": "Nuggets' Jokic scoops third NBA Most Valuable Player award", "body": "Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic was named NBA Most valuable Player for the third time in four seasons on Wednesday.\n\nThe 29-year-old Serbian star, who won the award in 2021 and 2022, finished runner-up in the voting in 2023 but had the satisfaction of leading the Nuggets to a first NBA title.\n\nThis season he averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists in the regular season and beat out Oklahoma City Thunder star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks in final voting for the award.\n\nHe became the second player, after Oscar Robertson, to record 2,000 points, 900 rebounds and 600 assists in a season.\n\nHis 25 triple-doubles and 68 double-doubles were both second in the league.\n\nJokic enters elite territory with a third MVP crown. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's six MVPs are the most ever. Bill Russell and Michael Jordan won five apiece and Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James four.\n\nJokic joins Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson as three-time winners after earning 79 first-placed votes compared to 15 for Gilgeous-Alexander and four for Doncic.\n\nBehind Jokic, the 57-25 Nuggets matched the franchise high for victories in a season -- although they were tied for best record in the West with Oklahoma City and ended up with the second seed.\n\nWhether Jokic will be able to combine an MVP award and the title this season remains to be seen.\n\nThe Nuggets dropped the first two games of their Western Conference semi-final series to the Minnesota Timberwolves and face the tough task of trying to claw back on the Timberwolves' home court starting on Friday.\n\nJokic's victory marks the sixth straight season that the MVP award has gone to a player born outside the United States. The last US-born player to win was James Harden in 2018.\n\nbb/rcw\n\nMore from this section\n\nFormer Addict Dedicates Himself to Paying Help Forward With Foundation for a Drug-Free World TikTok sues 1, "label": {"eng": "Western Conference (NBA)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma_City", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Oklahoma City"}, "location": {"type": "place", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9550375", "eventUri": "eng-9550375", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3725490196078431, "wgt": 185, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8118238805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:23:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:23:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:22:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://wtop.com/sports/2024/05/inside-the-nba-mvp-race-jokics-consistency-was-key-and-no-1-picks-were-denied-the-trophy-again/", "title": "Inside the NBA MVP Race: Jokic's consistency was key, and No. 1 picks were denied the trophy again - WTOP News", "body": "A look at some notes and numbers surrounding the NBA's MVP race this season: ___ MULTIPLE TOP 10s Denver's Nikola...\n\nA look at some notes and numbers surrounding the NBA's MVP race this season:\n\nDenver's Nikola Jokic was the only player in the league to rank among the top 10 in points (10th), rebounds (4th) and assists (3rd) per game this season, which surely went a long way toward voters giving him the MVP award for the third time in four years.\n\nThere were only three other players who ranked among top 10 in two of those categories.\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic won the scoring title and was second in assists per game. Milwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo was second in points and sixth in rebounds per game, and Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis led the league in rebounds per game while ranking sixth in assists per contest.\n\nThere's a reasonable chance that Victor Wembanyama -- the No. 1 pick in last year's draft by San Antonio, along with the rookie of the year winner and runner-up to Minnesota's Rudy Gobert for defensive player of the year this season -- wins the MVP award one day.\n\nBut Nikola Jokic's win this year extended an unusual streak.\n\nFor the 11th straight year, the MVP award was claimed by someone who wasn't a No. 1 overall draft pick. That's the longest such run in NBA history; the last No. 1 to win was LeBron James, then of Miami, in 2013.\n\nNikola Jokic is the fifth player in NBA history to finish first or second in the MVP balloting in at least four consecutive seasons. He won the award in 2021, 2022 and this year, and was second to Philadelphia's Joel Embiid in 2023.\n\nBoston Celtics greats Bill Russell and Larry Bird each were first or second in the balloting in six consecutive seasons. Russell won in 1958, 1961, 1962 and 1963, while finishing second in 1959 and 1960; Bird was second in 1981, 1982 and 1983 before winning in 1984, 1985 and 1986.\n\nKareem Abdul-Jabbar (1971-74) and Tim Duncan (2001-04) are the other players with four straight top-two finishes.\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic averaged 33.9 points, 9.2 rebounds and 9.8 assists per game this season. There had never been a season in NBA history in which someone finished with all those averages.\n\nAnd he still didn't win MVP.\n\nThere were 14 previous instances of someone averaging at least 33 points and nine rebounds; those stats were enough to MVP five times (Joel Embiid in 2023, Bob McAdoo in 1975, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar in 1972, Wilt Chamberlain in 1960 and 1966).\n\nOf course, it should be noted that Chamberlain had some years when he was even more dominant and didn't win MVP -- including five consecutive seasons in which he averaged at least 34 points and 22 rebounds but didn't get the trophy in any of them. Elgin Baylor averaged at least 34 points and 14 rebounds in three seasons when he wasn't MVP, and Rick Barry had a 35.6-point, 9.2-rebound year that didn't get him the award, either.\n\nBefore Doncic this year, there was just one season in which a player averaged at least 33 points and nine assists. That was 1972-73 when Tiny Archibald averaged 34 points and 11.4 assists for Kansas City. He was third in the MVP voting that season.\n\nNikola Jokic's win means a player who is listed at 6-foot-10 or taller -- Giannis Antetokounmpo in 2019 and 2020, Jokic in 2021, 2022 and now 2024, and Joel Embiid in 2023 -- has won the MVP award in six consecutive seasons.\n\nThat's a first for the NBA. But that doesn't mean this is the first dominant stretch for big men. Far from it.\n\nThere was a 16-year stretch from 1964-65 through 1979-80 when players generally considered to be centers or at least power forwards won the award each year. Not all were at least 6-10, but all were considered big men.\n\nThe last guard to win the MVP award was James Harden, then of Houston, in 2018.\n\nMilwaukee's Giannis Antetokounmpo got one first-place vote. It mattered.\n\nAntetokounmpo has now gotten at least one first-place MVP vote in six consecutive seasons, extending the longest such streak in the league.\n\nIt's the longest first-place-vote streak since LeBron James got a first-place vote in eight consecutive years from 2008 through 2015. That run ended when Golden State's Stephen Curry became the first -- and still only -- unanimous MVP in 2016.\n\nDenver's Nikola Jokic has gotten a first-place vote in each of the last four years. Philadelphia's Joel Embiid had first-place votes in each of the previous three seasons but was ineligible for consideration this year because of the league's new rule mandating that players must appear in a certain number of games before getting onto the ballot.\n\nLeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers didn't get a vote in the MVP balloting this season. It's only the second time in his 21-year career that has happened; the other was last season, ending an unprecedented 19-year streak of getting at least one vote. (The panel of reporters and broadcasters who vote on awards rank their top five MVP choices on their ballots.)\n\nHe is the only player in NBA history to appear in the MVP results in 19 different seasons. When the All-NBA team is revealed later this month, James could make a 20th appearance, which would extend his record.\n\nNo other player has more than 15 All-NBA nods.\n\nHere's a wrapup of all the NBA awards that have been announced to this point:\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-05-349605233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:07:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:07:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:03:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://milehighsports.com/nikola-jokic-wins-third-mvp-in-last-four-seasons-to-join-elite-nba-hierarchy-luka-doncic-shai-gilgeous-alexander/", "title": "Nikola Jokic wins third MVP in last four seasons to join elite NBA hierarchy - Mile High Sports", "body": "Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic was awarded the 2023-24 NBA MVP award tonight.\n\nJokic was announced as the MVP winner as part of Inside the NBA on TNT, holding off finalists Shai-Gilgeous Alexander and Luka Doncic for the award.\n\nThe Serbian superstar joins a select group of NBA royalty as the only players to receive the award three times in their career. Bill Russell, Wilt Chamberlain, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Moses Malone, Larry Bird, Magic Johnson, Michael Jordan, and LeBron James are the eight players to receive the award three or more times. Jokic becomes the ninth player to do so.\n\nJokic finished the 2023-24 regular season with 79 games played, a career high in total minutes, and mostly replicated his per game averages of the last four years that made him so valuable in the first place. He produced 26.4 points, 12.0 rebounds, 9.0 assists, and 1.4 steals per game, very much in line with what many expect of him. While Jokic has never led in any one category, it's his versatility to impact all categories that makes him so unique, On the season, Jokic ranked fifth in the entire NBA in total points scored, third in total rebounds, second in total assists, and eighth in total steals.\n\nVia Denver Nuggets PR:\n\nJoki\u0107 registered 25 triple-doubles, one shy of the NBA lead and 68 double-doubles, the most double-doubles in a season in franchise history. He now has had 20+ triple-doubles in consecutive seasons, becoming one of four players in NBA history (Robertson, Westbrook, Chamberlain) to record 20+ triple-doubles in multiple seasons. Joki\u0107 finished with a career-high 708 assists, passing Wilt Chamberlain for the most by a center in a single season in NBA history and moved him into second place all-time for most assists by a center. It also marks his fifth straight season with 550+ assists, tying Fat Lever for most such seasons in franchise history.\n\nThe Nuggets as a whole won 57 games, tying a franchise record. They ultimately finished as the second seed in the Western Conference, though they flirted with first place for much of the year as well. Somehow, there are no other Nuggets in consideration for other awards with no other All-Stars, All-Defensive Players, or any other national recognitions for the rest of the team. And yet, the Nuggets still found a way to dominate for most of the year. That's because they have Jokic, who has operated and handled as much responsibility as any one player should have to carry for a long time.\n\nThis season doesn't seem like it's going to go Denver's way, but that shouldn't take away from the season Jokic had. It's funny, the three times over the last four years that Jokic has won the award appear to be heading toward disappointment. The one year that Jokic probably should have won, the Nuggets won a championship.\n\nIt's an unfortunate quirk, but that appears to be Jokic and Denver's lot in life.\n\nPerhaps this moment can serve as a catalyst to turn around Denver's playoff series against the Minnesota Timberwolves where they currently trail 2-0. But even if it doesn't, it's important to appreciate these moments along the way. These opportunities are fleeting, and they deserve to be cherished. Jokic will only ever be in the prime of his career once, and it's important to value that as much as the Nuggets - the organization and the fans - possibly can.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8118203854", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:39:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:39:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:38:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/40109006/nuggets-nikola-jokic-wins-nba-mvp-3rd-4-seasons", "title": "Nuggets' Jokic claims third MVP in four seasons", "body": "Ohm Youngmisuk has covered the Giants, Jets and the NFL since 2006. Prior to that, he covered the Nets, Knicks and the NBA for nearly a decade. He joined ESPNNewYork.com after working at the New York Daily News for almost 12 years and is a graduate of Michigan State University.\n\nFollow him on Twitter \" Ohm's chat archive \"\n\nDenver Nuggets superstar Nikola Jokic continued to add to his legacy as one of the best NBA players ever Wednesday by winning his third Most Valuable Player trophy.\n\nJokic is the first center in six decades to win MVP three times in four seasons; Kareem Abdul-Jabbar did it from 1973-74 to 1976-77.\n\n\"It's hard to differentiate greatness from greatness from greatness,\" Denver head coach Michael Malone said in early April of how Jokic has gotten better from previous MVP seasons. \"And then that's what he's been over multiple years now. I know the last six years now, we've had by far the best record in the Western Conference and only second of the NBA behind, I think Milwaukee in that time.\"\n\nIn his ninth season, Jokic played 79 games, his most since playing 80 games during the 2018-19 season. He joined Wilt Chamberlain as the only players in NBA history to finish top-five in total points (fifth), rebounds (third) and assists (second) in multiple seasons, according to research by ESPN Stats & Information. Elgin Baylor is the only other player to do so once.\n\nJokic is also the second player to record 2,000 points, 900 rebounds and 600 assists in a season, joining Oscar Robertson.\n\nJokic averaged 26.4 points, 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists -- all top 10 in each statistical category. He had 25 triple-doubles, second only to Sacramento's Domantas Sabonis (26), while averaging 58.3% shooting from the field and 35.9% from behind the arc.\n\nPowered by Jokic, Denver finished the season fifth in offensive efficiency, eighth in defensive efficiency, and fourth in net rating. The Nuggets were one of four teams to rank top-10 in all three, along with the Celtics, Knicks and Thunder.\n\nWhile Denver boasted the best starting five in the league, Jokic's value was undeniable to Denver. The Nuggets posted a plus-11.8 net efficiency when Jokic was on the court but a minus-8.6 when he was off. Jokic led the NBA with a plus-682 plus-minus. The Nuggets were minus-251 with their franchise player off the court.\n\nOf course, the humble Jokic often says he doesn't care about individual honors as much as he covets the championship. Jokic is trying to lead the Nuggets to a repeat as world champs.\n\nShould he do so, the Nuggets big man will have put together a four-year run that only four other all-time greats have ever done. LeBron James, Magic Johnson, Larry Bird and Bill Russell are the only players to win three regular-season MVPs and two titles in a four-year span.\n\n\"Nikola has matured, his ability to continue to make everyone around him better,\" Malone said. \"And when you win a championship, and we're going to run it back, but in place of Bruce [Brown] and Jeff [Green], we're going to try to put young players in and the fact that we have a better record than we did last year.\n\n\"And we've had Jamal Murray miss [23] games. It speaks to Nikola understanding it's still my responsibility as a great player to help [the younger role players] as well as all the other guys to understand what their roles are, how to play on both ends of the floor, and most importantly, make those guys better.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118201824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:37:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:37:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:36:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/sports/nba/nuggets-nikola-jokic-2023-24-nba-mvp-award/3407812/", "title": "Nuggets' Nikola Jokic wins 3rd NBA MVP Award", "body": "Nikola Jokic may not care much for individual accolades, but that hasn't stopped him from collecting them.\n\nThe Denver Nuggets star added to his trophy room on Wednesday when he was named the 2023-24 NBA MVP, marking the third time he has earned the honor in the last four seasons.\n\nJokic is the ninth player in NBA history to win three MVPs, joining Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (6), Bill Russell (5), Michael Jordan (5), Wilt Chamberlain (4), LeBron James (4), Moses Malone (3), Larry Bird (3) and Magic Johnson (3).\n\nThe Serbian center earned his first two MVP awards in 2020-21 and 2021-22 before placing second in 2022-23 voting behind Philadelphia 76ers center Joel Embiid. He more than made up for it in the 2023 postseason, though, earning NBA Finals MVP honors after leading the Nuggets to their first NBA championship.\n\nThe 29-year-old center had another remarkably efficient regular season in 2023-24. He averaged 26.4 points per game, 12.4 rebounds per game and 9.0 assists per game while posting 25 triple-doubles.\n\nDenver finished as the No. 2 seed in the Western Conference with a 57-25 record. {"uri": "2024-05-349630112", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:01:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:01:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:48:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/nuggets-news-shaq-nikola-jokic-shai-gilgeous-alexander-mvp", "title": "Shaq tells Nuggets' Nikola Jokic that Shai Gilgeous-Alexander should have won MVP", "body": "In fact, Shaq even told Jokic his opinion on the matter while the Nuggets star was being interviewed on TNT's Inside the NBA, via ClutchPoints.\n\n\"I want you to hear from me first, but I think that SGA (Shai Gilgeous-Alexander) should have been the MVP,\" Shaq told Jokic. \"No disrespect to you.\"\n\nBefore interviewing Jokic, Shaq made it clear that he felt Gilgeous-Alexander should have won the award. His comments to Jokic may frustrate Nuggets fans, but at least he did not try to avoid the subject after his previous comments.\n\n\"I felt Shai deserved it,\" Shaq said after the initial announcement. \"I've been number two a lot, and I played my a** off number two so the fact that he has to start all over next year and try to win it again... I know this is going to be hurtful for him, hopefully he uses this to motivate him and win a championship.\n\n\"But I thought, and again no disrespect to the Joker (Nikola Jokic), best big man in the league by far... I thought Shai Gilgeous-Alexander was going to win it by far. But congratulations to the Joker, I'm happy for him.\"\n\nNikola Jokic wins his third MVP\n\nShaq may not have thought Jokic should have won, but there is no question that the Nuggets star enjoyed a tremendous campaign. He was initially selected as a finalist alongside Gilgeous-Alexander and Dallas Mavericks star Luka Doncic. Gilgeous-Alexander ultimately finished second in voting while Luka ended up in the third position.\n\nJokic, 29, already has three MVP awards now for his career. He is unquestionably on a Hall of Fame path.\n\nIn 2023-24, Jokic recorded 26.4 points per game on 58.3 percent field goal and 35.9 percent three-point shooting. He also recorded 12.4 rebounds and 9.0 assists per outing.\n\nThe Nuggets technically finished as the No. 2 seed in the Western Conference behind the Thunder. Denver and Oklahoma City finished the regular season with the exact same record, however. The Thunder earned the No. 1 seed because of a tiebreaker.\n\nRegardless, Jokic led the Nuggets to another stellar all-around campaign. Denver has developed a winning team that often produces impressive results. Jokic's teammates perform at a higher level when he is on the floor. He is a big man who is more than capable of getting everyone involved.\n\nIn all reality, each of the finalists had strong cases to win the award. Gilgeous-Alexander and Doncic both performed at elite levels throughout the 2023-24 campaign. It would not have been surprising to see either star end up winning the award.\n\nThe voters clearly felt that Nikola Jokic was deserving of winning the NBA MVP for the third time, however.\n\nDo you
